{"url": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/7011852/south-river-falls-trail", "title": "South River Falls Trail", "difficulty": "Intermediate/Difficult", "trailhead": "https://maps.google.com/?daddr=38.381127,-78.517032", "gpx": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/gpx/7011852", "info-text": {"description": "This trail heads past the drinking fountain at the South River picnic area. The trail begins by descending across the white-blazed Appalachian Trail (AT) and continues downhill along a straight, drawn-out stretch. The trail bends to the left, drops along several switchbacks, and then straightens out as the South River merges from the right (south).\r\n\nHead across the tributary stream, which can be hard to spot in places, but can be heard fairly clearly. After around a third of a mile, the trail will cross another stream. Here, the edge of the falls should start to come into view as the trees thin out, revealing views of the park beyond.\r\n\nFollow the trail for another hundred yards or so, and you'll arrive at a path on the right. This path dives very steeply toward the head of the falls and provides a number of slipping hazards to avoid. Stay straight on the South River Falls Trail as it leads to an observation point down on the right, toward the falls. Look for the ledge surrounded by a constructed guard wall. \r\n\nFrom here, you'll find the best views of the falls, out toward the gorge, and the northeast ridge of Saddleback Mountain beyond. The trail continues down where it ends at the South River Falls Road.  \r\n\nThanks to Larry W. Brown, for sharing this description. {"url": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/7011936/buck-hollow-trail", "title": "Buck Hollow Trail", "difficulty": "Intermediate", "trailhead": "https://maps.google.com/?daddr=38.638168,-78.313743", "gpx": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/gpx/7011936", "info-text": {"description": "This is a fairly easy and pleasant trail that heads downhill, mostly beside a stream, from Skyline Drive. Be aware as there are a couple rough stretches, but if you want to escape from the crowds, this is one of the better options in the park that is still easily accessible.\r\n\nBecause this is a one-way hike, you'll either have to leave a car at the bottom of the trail, plan for someone to meet you there, or use the trail as an out-and-back hike (doubling the distance to six miles). \r\n\nTo get to the eastern end of the trail, from Thornton Gap at mile 31.5, take U.S. 211 east toward Washington. Continue 3.7 miles to a small parking area off to the right. Look for the Buck Hollow Trail marked by a concrete post.\r\n\nFrom the trailhead off of Skyline Drive, the trail dives gradually at the beginning, then continues to gain in grade with some steep sections. The trail passes through a young forest of mostly mountain laurel, which is very nice to stroll through. Keep your eyes open for some dead hemlocks, many of which were destroyed by the hemlock wooly adelgid.\r\n\nAbout three-quarters of a mile from Skyline Drive, the trail bends to the right and crosses a rocky stream bed before descending along the ridge some distance from the stream. Further along, it bends back to the left, descends to the stream, and makes a sharp right. \r\n\nFrom here, watch for the blue blazes. After another quarter-mile, the trail turns left and crosses the stream, but this turn is often missed. Look out for the blue blazes! A double blaze means that the trail is about to change direction. If you think you may have missed the turn and are running out of trail, cross back to the left bank of the stream and you'll find the trail there, within a hundred feet of the water.\r\n\nFor a large stretch of the trail, you'll follow an old road that originally went to a sawmill further up in the hollow. Look out for these occasional traces of old logging road that join the trail, keeping with the blue blazes. \r\n\nThe park and Potomac Appalachian Trail Club trail crews have done thorough work in this area. The trail crosses the stream again and after another quarter of a mile leaves the old dirt road to become much smoother and narrower. The trail quickly crosses the Buck Hollow stream for the last time, then crosses the Thornton River. Both crossings are fairly easy unless the water is high from recent rains. \r\n\nAfter this last crossing, the parking area at U.S. 211 is less than 200 yards away, through what was once a grassy clearing near an old homesite.\r\n\nThanks to Larry W. Brown, for sharing this trail description. Check out his comprehensive Guide to Shenandoah National Park.", "features": "Birding \u00b7 Fall Colors \u00b7 Spring \u00b7 Wildflowers \u00b7 Wildlife", "condition": "Unknown"}, "photo": "https://www.hikingproject.com/photo/7017955/sunrise-view-from-buck-hollow-overlook", "ratings": {"rating": 4.1, "num_reviewers": 8}, "stats": {"dist": 3.0, "dist-type": "Point to Point", "alt-range": [2844, 1095], "alt-change": [18, 1750], "avg-grade": 11.0, "max-grade": 37.0}},
{"url": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/7011937/buck-ridge-trail", "title": "Buck Ridge Trail", "difficulty": "Intermediate/Difficult", "trailhead": "https://maps.google.com/?daddr=38.65542,-78.283497", "gpx": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/gpx/7011937", "info-text": {"description": "The beginning of this trail starts off the Buck Hollow Trail just after you have crossed two streams via large boulders. {"url": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/7011975/corbin-cabin-cutoff-trail", "title": "Corbin Cabin Cutoff Trail", "difficulty": "Intermediate/Difficult", "trailhead": "https://maps.google.com/?daddr=38.61562,-78.350502", "gpx": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/gpx/7011975", "info-text": {"description": "The upper half of the trail is fairly rough and descends at a steep grade while the lower half begins to level out. All along this hike, and others in this area, there is a lot of evidence of fire. The fires from 2009 destroyed the remains of many former home sites.\r\n\nThe trail begins across Skyline Drive from the Corbin Cabin Cutoff parking area. It descends along a ridge line through mountain laurels and young forest. Around a half-mile from the start, the trail bends to the left and drops the side of the ridge for a couple hundred yards, before it turns to the right beside an ephemeral stream. About another half-mile further, as the trail makes a turn to the right, keep an eye out for a stone wall on the right at a former homesite. This was the home of John R. Nicholson.\r\n\nContinuing on the trail, it's another third of a mile to Corbin Cabin. This stretch is rich in evidence of those that once lived in the area. There are ruins of several small farm buildings, old grape vines, and piles and walls of rock. The trail descends to cross a small stream and after a couple hundred yards, look for an old cemetery off the trail on the right-hand side. It can be hard to spot and the gravestones are blank. \r\n\nAfter crossing the Hughes River, you'll arrive at the junction with the Nicholson Hollow Trail. To the left (southeast), is a four-mile stretch downhill to State Route 600 (Nethers Road) and to the right (northwest) is a 1.8-mile climb to Skyline Drive.\r\n\nThanks to Larry W. Brown, for sharing this trail description. {"url": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/7011983/dry-run-falls-road", "title": "Dry Run Falls Road", "difficulty": "Intermediate", "trailhead": "https://maps.google.com/?daddr=38.384316,-78.517167", "gpx": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/gpx/7011983", "info-text": {"description": "On the west side of the Skyline Drive at the South River Overlook, mile 62.7, is the Dry Run Falls fire road which goes for about 2.0 miles to the park boundary. \r\n\nTwo items of interest along this fire road are Lost Cliffs and Dry Run Falls.\r\n\nThe Lost Cliffs are Greenstone that rise nearly 100 above the forest floor. You'll seen them to your right about 50 yards off the fire road. There's an unmarked footpath on the far end that will take you to the top. The cliffs are high enough above the forest cover to provide good views south and west.  \r\n\nThe Dry Run Falls are located well off the fire road. There is no trail (you must bushwhack), but it is worth a side trip by experienced hikers. About 1.8 miles from the start, the fire road makes a sharp turn to the right. After you complete the turn, the falls will be diagonally ahead and left, straight downhill, about an eighth of a mile away. If there's a good flow of water, you should be able to hear the falls from the fire road.\r\n\nThanks to Larry W. Brown, for sharing this trail description. If you\u2019re interested in learning more details about great hikes, weather, camping / lodging, wildlife, and scenic drives, check out the comprehensive Guide to Shenandoah National Park.", "features": "Waterfall \u00b7 Wildflowers \u00b7 Wildlife", "condition": "Unknown"}, "photo": "https://www.hikingproject.com/photo/7013833/the-lost-cliffs-loom-over-dry-run-falls-road", "ratings": {"rating": 3.3, "num_reviewers": 3}, "stats": {"dist": 3.0, "dist-type": "Point to Point", "alt-range": [2964, 1827], "alt-change": [0, 1137], "avg-grade": 7.0, "max-grade": 17.0}},
{"url": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/7011984/conway-river-road", "title": "Conway River Road", "difficulty": "Intermediate/Difficult", "trailhead": "https://maps.google.com/?daddr=38.439698,-78.435653", "gpx": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/gpx/7011984", "info-text": {"description": "Shenandoah National Park has over 500 miles of trails and roads for visitors to enjoy on foot or horseback. This is one of several old and seldom-used fire roads in the park that was built by the Civilian Conservation Corps. \r\n\nThe Civilian Conservation Corps was a part of President Franklin Roosevelt's New-Deal program. From 1933-1942, thousands of young men lived and worked in CCC camps in and adjacent to the park. The \"boys\" built rock walls, trails, fire roads, log structures, scenic overlooks, and more. They planted hundreds of thousands of trees and shrubs and are responsible for much of what visitors to Shenandoah see today. This year marks the 75th anniversary of the work of the CCC boys in Shenandoah National Park\r\n\nThese routes can range in grade, tread, and length and are often used on loops or as connections to more popular singletrack trails. {"url": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/7011989/crescent-rock-trail", "title": "Crescent Rock Trail", "difficulty": "Easy", "trailhead": "https://maps.google.com/?daddr=38.5634,-78.381629", "gpx": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/gpx/7011989", "info-text": {"description": "To access the start of the Crescent Rock Trail, cross Skyline Drive from the north end of the Crescent Rocks Cliffs parking area. Look for the sign that marks the trail around one hundred feet to the right. \r\n\nThe trail begins with a brief climb through some swaths of mountain laurel before descending the rest of the way along an old road. Look for the concrete marker post that marks the Limberlost Trail at the end of the Crescent Rock Trail. \r\n\nRemember, like most Skyline Drive trails, you'll have to ascend back to the start of this one. Plan accordingly with water, snacks, and layers. \r\n\nThanks to Larry W. Brown, for sharing this trail description. {"url": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/7011995/dark-hollow-falls-trail", "title": "Dark Hollow Falls Trail", "difficulty": "Intermediate", "trailhead": "https://maps.google.com/?daddr=38.519627,-78.430919", "gpx": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/gpx/7011995", "info-text": {"description": "Access the trailhead at the north end of the Dark Hollow Falls parking area. It crosses a stream and then goes downhill along its left bank. This is Hogcamp Branch, which drains Big Meadows Swamp and becomes the principal tributary of Rose River.\r\n\nThe trail descends easily for 0.6 mile to the head of the falls. You must stay on the trail here. There's no view from the top of the falls, and the rocks there are slippery and dangerous. The trail swings away from the stream and goes uphill for a few feet before swinging right and descending to the base of the falls. On the trail between the top and bottom of the falls, you'll pass a tremendous rock that looms on your left, just where the trail swings sharply to the right. Except in dry summer months, water constantly trickles and drips down the face of this rock, promoting the growth of mosses, ferns, and liverworts. On cold winter days there's an enchanting display of stalactites and stalagmites of ice.\r\n\nThere's a fine view of the falls from the bottom. The water drops 70 feet, in a series of cascades, over the crumbling greenstone of an ancient lava flow.\r\n\nBelow the falls, the trail descends another 145 feet in about 300 yards to the Rose River Fire Road, passing a number of small cascades, and then intersecting with a small waterfall that some call the lower Dark Hollow Falls. \r\n\nYou can return by the way you came, or cross the Rose River Fire Road and access the Rose River Loop Trail to explore further.\r\n\nThanks to Larry W. Brown, for sharing this trail description. If you\u2019re interested in learning more details about great hikes, weather, camping / lodging, wildlife, and scenic drives, check out the comprehensive Guide to Shenandoah National Park.", "features": "River/Creek \u00b7 Waterfall \u00b7 Wildflowers \u00b7 Wildlife", "condition": "Unknown"}, "photo": "https://www.hikingproject.com/photo/7037946/night-shot-of-dark-hollow-falls", "ratings": {"rating": 4.6, "num_reviewers": 18}, "stats": {"dist": 0.9, "dist-type": "Point to Point", "alt-range": [3414, 2874], "alt-change": [3, 544], "avg-grade": 12.0, "max-grade": 34.0}},

Turn right onto Nicholson Hollow trail for about 250 yards from the cabin, and then look to the left for the blue-blazed Indian Run Trail.\r\n\nLike many trails in Shenandoah, this was once an access road for the inhabitants of the area. The trail climbs steadily up to the saddle of Thorofare Mountain and dips off the other side to end at its junction with the Corbin Mtn Trail. This can be a fun trail for experienced hikers with lots of time.\r\n\nThanks to Larry W. Brown, for sharing this trail description. {"url": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/7012042/hazel-river-trail", "title": "Hazel River Trail", "difficulty": "Intermediate/Difficult", "trailhead": "https://maps.google.com/?daddr=38.614995,-78.261811", "gpx": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/gpx/7012042", "info-text": {"description": "This 3.3-mile trail starts at the valley floor and slowly climbs up a valley to cross the Hazel River four times. After the water has been crossed four times, the trail becomes steeper as it approaches the Hazel Mountain Trail.\r\n\nAccess and parking for the two trails starting in the valley is a bit challenging. Rte 600 (Woodstock Rd) is dirt and there are only about 5 spots to park near the junction of Hungry Horse Lane. You may not drive or park on Hungry Horse Lane.\r\n\nAfter parking in one of the few allowable parking spots, you'll hike up Hungry Horse Lane a couple hundred yards to the trailhead for the Hazel River Trail. The four crossings of the Hazel River may be unsafe to execute during the wet season, and it is advised to use Sams Ridge Trail instead. You can also create a nice loop by either starting or finishing with Sams Ridge Trail and connecting them with Hazel Mountain Trail.", "features": "Birding \u00b7 Fall Colors \u00b7 River/Creek \u00b7 Views \u00b7 Wildflowers \u00b7 Wildlife", "condition": "Unknown"}, "photo": "https://www.hikingproject.com/photo/7035791/hiking-across-the-hazel-river-during-low-water-season", "ratings": {"rating": 3.7, "num_reviewers": 7}, "stats": {"dist": 3.3, "dist-type": "Point to Point", "alt-range": [2617, 1142], "alt-change": [1502, 88], "avg-grade": 9.0, "max-grade": 25.0}},
{"url": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/7012043/graves-mill-trail", "title": "Graves Mill Trail", "difficulty": "Intermediate", "trailhead": "https://maps.google.com/?daddr=38.437271,-78.367157", "gpx": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/gpx/7012043", "info-text": {"description": "The Graves Mill Trail is a relatively easy hike that parallels the Rapidan River. The trailhead is a small gravel parking area at the end of Route 662. This is a no-fee entrance to Shenandoah National Park.\r\n\nThe trailhead is somewhat isolated but in a safe, rural area. This beautiful trail is well-marked and almost completely shaded during spring through fall. \r\n\nThe Rapidan River is a beautiful fast running stream that provides for catch and release fishing. The hike crosses two streams that most hikers find easy to cross using river rock/boulders. This is not a busy trail and it is normal to hike up and back and see only a few fellow hikers. \r\n\nThe closest store for food, drinks, and gas is in Wolftown, about seven miles from the trailhead. There are several trails that connect to Graves Mill trail if you want a longer route.", "features": "Birding \u00b7 Fall Colors \u00b7 River/Creek \u00b7 Spring \u00b7 Wildflowers", "condition": "All Clear"}, "photo": "https://www.hikingproject.com/photo/7018907/a-creek-crossing-made-up-of-large-rocks-and-boulders", "ratings": {"rating": 4.1, "num_reviewers": 11}, "stats": {"dist": 2.2, "dist-type": "Point to Point", "alt-range": [1332, 913], "alt-change": [434, 16], "avg-grade": 4.0, "max-grade": 11.0}},
{"url": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/7012058/hazel-mountain-trail", "title": "Hazel Mountain Trail", "difficulty": "Intermediate", "trailhead": "https://maps.google.com/?daddr=38.638231,-78.313779", "gpx": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/gpx/7012058", "info-text": {"description": "Head out for this trail at the south side of the Buck Hollow Trail Parking Area. Look for a trail sign and the yellow blazes that mark the start of the trail. After about three-tenths of a mile from the parking area, the Buck Ridge Trail comes in on the left. \r\n\nContinue downhill through an area that was heavily burned in the fires of 2000, but still has some large trees and old mountain laurel bushes. \r\n\nAfter around one and a half miles from Skyline Drive, the trail forks, with the White Rocks Trail (yellow-blazed) heading left. Continue straight and east, to the low point of the trail just past the Catlett Spur Trail that heads to the right and west. \r\n\nFrom here, the trail begins to gradually climb for three-quarters of a mile, crossing Hazel River, up to where Hazel River Trail heads off to the left and north. Continue for a few hundred yards as the trail begins to bend to the right, heading past where the Sams Ridge Trail meets the trail on the left side.\r\n\nOne more mile, passing the Catlett Mtn Trail off to the right, to the end of the trail at the junction with Hot Mtn-Short Mtn Trail and Pine Hill Gap Trail.\r\n\nThanks to Larry W. Brown, for sharing this trail description. {"url": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/7012059/hannah-run-trail", "title": "Hannah Run Trail", "difficulty": "Difficult", "trailhead": "https://maps.google.com/?daddr=38.6224,-78.322798", "gpx": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/gpx/7012059", "info-text": {"description": "The trail starts through an opening in the wall at the north end of the overlook. It falls along the ridge top with a couple switchbacks, and has a nicer tread than most of the blue-blazed trails. For a stretch of this hike, you can see the results of the 2000 fires. Around a half a mile from the start, at the right side of the trail, is a pretty unusual \"deer\" tree - a result of damage that occurred a few years ago during an ice storm. The trail continues downhill, with a few brief and easy climbs to head around two knobs on the ridge crest.\r\n\nAfter about a mile from Skyline Drive, at a concrete marker post, the Hannah Run Trail bends ninety degrees to the right, at the junction with the Catlett Mtn Trail. Up to now, the trail has been fairly new and is periodically cleared for park visitors. Heading further, however, the trail transitions back into an old mountain trail, leading to the first homesite and then what used to be a road.\r\n\nAfter you turn right at the junction, the trail is almost level until it begins to descend, gradually and then much more steeply. The next few hundred yards are steep and slippery. Descend to Hannah Run and then ascend the ridge on the other side. Go around forty yards more, and look out for the piles of stones off to the right. These are all that remains of an early building here.\r\n\nAfter another forty yards, the trail makes a quick left turn, at the corner of another former homesite. Similarly to the first, all that remains is the stone foundation.\r\n\nThe next former homesite (lost in a fire) is two-tenths of a mile further, off to the left. It's smaller and older than the first. After another couple hundred yards, look for the third and oldest ruin. Only the chimney and some stones from the foundation remain.\r\n\nFrom here, it becomes more apparent that the trail follows an old road. There are numerous piles of rocks on both sides of the trail that mark locations of previous fences, outbuildings, and homes. This is a delightful stroll as the surrounding woods are open with views and some good sized trees. Hannah Run is down a small ravine on your left. The grade of the trail is gentle.\r\n\nA mile and a half from the final ruin, the Hannah Run Trail ends at the Nicholson Hollow Trail. Heading right, it's a little over two miles to Corbin Cabin, and just under four miles to Skyline Drive at mile 38.4. To the left it's two miles to the Weakley Hollow Fire Road.\r\n\nThanks to Larry W. Brown, for sharing this trail description. If you\u2019re interested in learning more details about great hikes, weather, camping / lodging, wildlife, and scenic drives, check out the comprehensive Guide to Shenandoah National Park.", "features": "Birding \u00b7 Fall Colors \u00b7 River/Creek \u00b7 Spring \u00b7 Wildflowers \u00b7 Wildlife", "condition": "Unknown"}, "photo": "https://www.hikingproject.com/photo/7017961/winter-morning-view-from-the-pinnacles-overlook", "ratings": {"rating": 3.7, "num_reviewers": 3}, "stats": {"dist": 3.6, "dist-type": "Point to Point", "alt-range": [3318, 1368], "alt-change": [8, 1959], "avg-grade": 10.0, "max-grade": 35.0}},
{"url": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/7012061/hawksbill-trailbyrds-nest-2-road", "title": "Hawksbill Trail/Byrds Nest #2 Road", "difficulty": "Intermediate", "trailhead": "https://maps.google.com/?daddr=38.544911,-78.400206", "gpx": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/gpx/7012061", "info-text": {"description": "Access the start of this fire road at mile 47.1 along the Skyline Drive. You'll have a steady, easy climb through a young oak forest. \r\n\nThe fire road also intersects with the Upper Hawksbill Trail, which will be on the right. Keep going straight on the fire road.\r\n\nAfter another quarter of a mile, the blue-blazed Salamander Trail on the left goes about 0.8 mile to the Appalachian Trail; to the right, the Lower Hawksbill Trail goes to Hawksbill Gap, at mile 45.6 along the Skyline Drive. Continue ahead on the fire road to the Byrds Nest shelter, then go another 75 yards to the observation platform on the summit. \r\n\nThe summit on Hawksbill is at elevation 4,050 feet, the highest point in Shenandoah National Park. There's a broad view here. At the far left is the town of Stanley; just to the right of it, and much closer, is the rounded crest of Nakedtop, with cliffs on its right-hand slope. To the right of Nakedtop is Buracker Hollow, with the town of Ida at its mouth. From Ida a ridge rises toward the right to the angle at Millers Head, then to the rounded summit of Bushytop. The high point, with rocky cliffs on its left face, is Stony Man. Further right and closer, down below you, is Crescent Rock. Still farther right, in the distance, is the rocky summit of Old Rag. \r\n\nPlease note that camping is not permitted on or near Hawksbill summit.", "features": "Views \u00b7 Wildflowers \u00b7 Wildlife", "condition": "Unknown"}, "photo": "https://www.hikingproject.com/photo/7083551/view-from-hawksbill-peak", "ratings": {"rating": 3.0, "num_reviewers": 1}, "stats": {"dist": 0.9, "dist-type": "Point to Point", "alt-range": [4037, 3579], "alt-change": [458, 2], "avg-grade": 10.0, "max-grade": 16.0}},

{"url": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/7012092/lewis-spring-pumphouse-road", "title": "Lewis Spring Pumphouse Road", "difficulty": "Easy/Intermediate", "trailhead": "https://maps.google.com/?daddr=38.516935,-78.441645", "gpx": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/gpx/7012092", "info-text": {"description": "This gravel service road provides the easiest access to Lewis Spring Falls, though the slightly longer Lewis Falls Trail circuit trail from the Big Meadows amphitheater area is suggested.\r\n\nFollow the road downhill, which crosses a horse trail and also the Appalachian Trail. You'll pass a short side trail on the left that goes about 100 feet to Lewis Spring. It's completely enclosed; you'll hear gushing water behind the padlocked door. This spring is not only the principal source of water for the Big Meadows development; it's also the source of Hawksbill Creek, which forms Lewis Spring Falls and then, much later, flows through the town of Luray before joining the Shenandoah River.\r\n\nContinue 30 yards to a locked door in the hillside on your right; behind it is a pump for the Big Meadows water supply that sends most of the output of Lewis Spring up to the underground storage tanks on Blackrock.\r\n\nAfter another 30 yards you can opt to turn left onto the blue-blazed Lewis Falls Trail.\r\n\nThanks to Larry W. Around twenty-five yards from the start, the trail takes a sharp switchback to the left, keep your eyes open for the blue blazes to stay on the trail. \r\n\nThe Meadow Spring is just under a half mile from Skyline Drive, off the trail on the right, just before the trail makes a 90-degree turn to the right. {"url": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/7012104/pocosin-trail", "title": "Pocosin Trail", "difficulty": "Intermediate", "trailhead": "https://maps.google.com/?daddr=38.401306,-78.482024", "gpx": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/gpx/7012104", "info-text": {"description": "Hiking this trail is like taking a step back into history, with visible ruins of what once was in these mountains, before it became a national park at the turn of the 20th century.\r\n\nLook for a concrete marker post on the right, near the start of this yellow-blazed Pocosin Trail. As you turn onto the trail, the first ruin of a wooden structure is about 100 feet diagonally left. It was part of the Episcopal mission here (named the Pocosin Mission). Explore if you wish, remembering that snakes like to take cover in such areas.\r\n\n20 yards from the house ruins are the steps of a church that doubled as a schoolhouse. The church is gone, and its foundation is covered with vegetation. To date, sections of the rock walls of a small side room are still standing.\r\n\n25 yards beyond the church steps are the ruins of a wooden structure, now long gone, under a large chestnut oak. The vines on the upper limbs of the oak are loaded with grapes in autumn - but way up out of reach. On the other side of the Pocosin Trail, which once was a road, is an abandoned, overgrown cemetery with fieldstone markers, and the site of at least two houses.\r\n\nThanks to Larry W. Continue along on the dirt road. \r\n\nFrom this point on, you'll begin to see traces of the former residents of this area such as old road traces and pioneer species of trees, which suggest areas where the vegetation has been cleared. \r\n\nA little more than a half mile from the white-blazed AT, the road passes a grassy clearing on the left, where there used to be a homesite. There is a pit toilet to the right. \r\n\nThanks to Larry W. Brown, for sharing this trail description. {"url": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/7012128/passamaquoddy-trail-north", "title": "Passamaquoddy Trail - North", "difficulty": "Difficult", "trailhead": "https://maps.google.com/?daddr=38.59701,-78.379697", "gpx": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/gpx/7012128", "info-text": {"description": "From the Stony Man Trail parking area, head along the sidewalk to the west (away from Sklyine Drive), and go around 50 feet beyond the parking area until you reach the yellow-blazed Furnace Spring Horse Trail. This trail is one option to get to the start of the Passamaquoddy Trail - North.\r\n\nInstead of heading out on the horse trail, turn left toward the Skyland Lower Loop paved road, and turn right. Continue next to the road, keeping to the right where it forks. The Passamaquoddy Trail - South crosses the road around two-tenths of a mile from the parking area. Turn right on the trail, heading north, and continue for about two-tenths of a mile to a dirt road, and turn right. \r\n\nPass a seldom used side road that climbs uphill to the right, and continue to a fork in the road. The right fork goes fifty yards to a no-longer-used pump house, while the left fork, with a yellow chain, is the old Skyland Road, which provided access to Skyland before Skyline Drive was built. \r\n\nThe Passamaquoddy Trail - North resumes on the far side of the road, at a concrete marker post. Fifty yards from the marker, the enclosed pump house at Furnace Spring is set into the hillside on the right. This spring once provided water to a copper smelter, giving the spring its name.\r\n\nThe 0.8-mile section of trail between Furnace Spring and Little Stony Man is the original Passamaquoddy Trail.  In 1932, George Freeman Pollock, the owner of Skyland, had a trail built between these points. A number of traces of the old trail can still be seen just a few feet up the bank. Pollock called this the Passamaquoddy Trail because, he said, Passamaquoddy is a Maine Indian word meaning \"abounding in pollock\" (an abundant saltwater fish on the Maine coast).\r\n\nThe trail continues, with some ups and downs, along the steep slope below the Stony Man cliffs. Less than half a mile beyond the spring, where the trail is wide and nearly level, look for the big overhanging rocks to the right. In wet weather they trickle, and in winter they are usually covered with icicles. The Stony Man Cliffs are immediately up the slope, towering above you. Please remain on the trail or on bare rock to protect the plantlife.\r\n\nThanks to Larry W. Brown, for sharing this trail description. {"url": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/7012152/skyland-big-meadows-horse-trail", "title": "Skyland-Big Meadows Horse Trail", "difficulty": "Intermediate/Difficult", "trailhead": "https://maps.google.com/?daddr=38.556214,-78.376769", "gpx": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/gpx/7012152", "info-text": {"description": "Shenandoah National Park has over 500 miles of trails for visitors to enjoy, over 180 of which are open to horse use. This is one of several horse trails that can range in grade, tread, and length. Visitors are encouraged to take part in one of the parks guided trail tours that are offered from the spring season through the fall. For more information on guided horseback tours, see the parks website. \r\n\nVisitors are also allowed to bring their own horses to experience the horse trails on their own. For more information on horse trails and personal horse use within the park, please visit the parks website, or call (540) 999-3500.", "features": "Birding \u00b7 Fall Colors \u00b7 River/Creek \u00b7 Spring \u00b7 Views \u00b7 Wildflowers \u00b7 Wildlife", "condition": "Unknown"}, "photo": "https://www.hikingproject.com/photo/7010458/along-skyline-drive", "ratings": {"rating": 2.0, "num_reviewers": 4}, "stats": {"dist": 7.2, "dist-type": "Point to Point", "alt-range": [3685, 2910], "alt-change": [1166, 1018], "avg-grade": 6.0, "max-grade": 20.0}},
{"url": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/7012153/rose-river-fire-road", "title": "Rose River Fire Road", "difficulty": "Easy/Intermediate", "trailhead": "https://maps.google.com/?daddr=38.533472,-78.420867", "gpx": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/gpx/7012153", "info-text": {"description": "Park at the Fishers Gap Overlook and head out the north entrance. Cross the Skyline Drive to access the fire road. A hundred feet down the fire road you'll see a trail to the left, which is the start of the Rose River Loop trail. If you opt to do that circuit, you'll be returning up this fire road. Otherwise, continue straight down the fire road.\r\n\nYou'll eventually pass by the Cave family cemetery, located on the right, just off the fire road. About 0.6 mile further down you'll come to a small bridge which crosses Hogcamp Branch, the stream which drains Big Meadows Swamp, flows through Dark Hollow, and becomes the principal tributary of Rose River.\r\n\nTo your right is a long, narrow waterfall, which descends from Dark Hollow Falls. You'll see the blue-blazed Dark Hollow Falls Trail to your right, which goes uphill. If you make a side trip to the base of the falls you'll add 0.3 mile and 145 feet of climbing to your outing. To the left of the bridge you'll see the loop trail (mentioned above) which connects back to the fire road.\r\n\nContinue down the fire road as it descends through the Rose River Valley to the park boundary, where it then becomes Virginia Route 670.\r\n\nThanks to Larry W. {"url": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/7012157/staunton-river-trail", "title": "Staunton River Trail", "difficulty": "Intermediate/Difficult", "trailhead": "https://maps.google.com/?daddr=38.443364,-78.369744", "gpx": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/gpx/7012157", "info-text": {"description": "The Staunton River Trail is a moderately difficult trail that parallels the Staunton River. The trail is mostly uphill, frequently with a narrow one-person pathway. \r\n\nTo get to the Staunton River Trailhead, drive to Graves Mill, Virginia and take Route 662 north until its end. You'll arrive at a small gravel parking area. This is a no fee entrance to Shenandoah National Park. The trailhead is somewhat isolated but in a safe, rural area. \r\n\nTake the Graves Mill Trai 1/2 mile and look for the concrete trailhead marker on the left. This beautiful four-mile trail is well marked and almost completely shaded during spring through fall. It is often used to make a longer out-and-back hike. \r\n\nThere are multiple views of the Staunton River highlighted with beautiful but small waterfalls, huge river boulders, and cool breezes off the stream rushing downhill. The trail is bordered with local wildflowers and with occasional wild blackberry and raspberry bushes. \r\n\nThe surrounding forest is mostly poplar and oak with thick undergrowth. The trail intersects with the Jones Mountain Trail at the 2.2-mile marker. This trail leads to the historic Jones Mountain Cabin which can be rented from the Potomac Appalachian Trail Club.  \r\n\nAnother side trail leads to Bear Church Rock that provides spectacular mountain and valley views. This trail is open only to hikers. No horses or bikes allowed. This is not a busy trail and it is normal to hike up and back and see only a few fellow hikers. The closest store for food, drink and gas is in Wolftown, about seven miles from the trailhead.", "features": "Birding \u00b7 Fall Colors \u00b7 River/Creek \u00b7 Waterfall", "condition": "All Clear"}, "photo": "https://www.hikingproject.com/photo/7018907/a-creek-crossing-made-up-of-large-rocks-and-boulders", "ratings": {"rating": 3.9, "num_reviewers": 10}, "stats": {"dist": 4.0, "dist-type": "Point to Point", "alt-range": [2981, 984], "alt-change": [2000, 4], "avg-grade": 9.0, "max-grade": 25.0}},

{"url": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/7012163/skyland-road", "title": "Skyland Road", "difficulty": "Difficult", "trailhead": "https://maps.google.com/?daddr=38.613732,-78.396693", "gpx": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/gpx/7012163", "info-text": {"description": "Shenandoah National Park has over 500 miles of trails and roads for visitors to enjoy on foot or horseback. This is one of several old and seldom-used fire roads in the park that was built by the Civilian Conservation Corps. \r\n\nThe Civilian Conservation Corps was a part of President Franklin Roosevelt's New-Deal program. From 1933-1942, thousands of young men lived and worked in CCC camps in and adjacent to the park. The \"boys\" built rock walls, trails, fire roads, log structures, scenic overlooks, and more. They planted hundreds of thousands of trees and shrubs and are responsible for much of what visitors to Shenandoah see today. This year marks the 75th anniversary of the work of the CCC boys in Shenandoah National Park\r\n\nThese routes can range in grade, tread, and length and are often used on loops or as connections to more popular singletrack trails. {"url": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/7012193/sams-ridge-trail", "title": "Sams Ridge Trail", "difficulty": "Difficult", "trailhead": "https://maps.google.com/?daddr=38.614848,-78.262512", "gpx": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/gpx/7012193", "info-text": {"description": "This 2.2-mile trail takes you on a steep path from the valley floor and up to the junction of Broad Hollow Trail and Hazel Mountain Trail. If the water levels are high on the Hazel River Trail, this trail will provide you with a safe passage into the Shenandoah National Park.\r\n\nAccess and parking for the two trails starting in the valley is a bit challenging. Rte 600 (Woodstock Rd) is dirt and there are only about 5 spots to park near the junction of Hungry Horse Ln. You may not drive or park on Hungry Horse Ln.  After parking in one of the few allowable parking spots, you'll hike up Hungry Horse Ln a couple of hundred yards to the trailhead of the Hazel River Trail.\r\n\nAbout 100 yards up on the right you'll find the trailhead marker for Sams Ridge Trail, and from this point on the trail is a steep climb that follows the ridgeline. Near the top of the trail, you'll run into a few short sections that allow a break from the climb. Overall, the trail is a thigh buster the entire way. If you want to create a great loop, you can pair this trail with the Hazel River Trail and return to your car with a nice hike following the creek.", "features": "Fall Colors \u00b7 Wildflowers \u00b7 Wildlife", "condition": "Unknown"}, "photo": "https://www.hikingproject.com/photo/7035788/the-terminus-of-sams-ridge-trail", "ratings": {"rating": 3.2, "num_reviewers": 6}, "stats": {"dist": 2.2, "dist-type": "Point to Point", "alt-range": [2625, 1184], "alt-change": [1443, 44], "avg-grade": 13.0, "max-grade": 31.0}},
{"url": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/7012194/rose-river-loop-trail", "title": "Rose River Loop Trail", "difficulty": "Intermediate/Difficult", "trailhead": "https://maps.google.com/?daddr=38.534083,-78.414238", "gpx": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/gpx/7012194", "info-text": {"description": "A two+ -mile trail through federally designated wilderness areas with streams, cascades, and 2 waterfalls (the upper & lower Rose River falls).  When water levels are sufficient, the pure wilderness scenery and abundant flowing streams along this trail is spectacular in any season.\r\n\nThe beginning of this trail is at the intersection of a foot trail and horse trail combined (see Skyland-Big Meadows Horse Trail). The horse trail turns off to the left, while the loop trail continues straight ahead on the blue-blazed trail.\r\n\nA hundred yards beyond, the Rose River comes down on the left and parallels the trail. As you go, the stream is rarely out of sight, and it has an endless variety of cascades and pools. After another quarter of a mile you're at the upper Rose River falls, which consist of several separate cascades. Just below the upper falls, off the trail, you can opt to walk down steeper terrain into a rock gorge, where the lower Rose River falls will come into view from your left.\r\n\nContinuing along the trail after leaving the waterfalls, you'll descend to flatter terrain. The trail will now parallel another stream, to your left, named Hogcamp Branch, which drains Big Meadows Swamp, and flows through Dark Hollow, then becomes the principal tributary of Rose River. \r\n\nFurther along the trail you'll approach the filled-in shaft of an old copper mine, to its left is a weathered concrete block; it supported an air compressor that supplied the pneumatic drills. Less than a tenth of a mile beyond the copper mine, cross the foot bridge over Hogcamp Branch and turn right. The trail ascends through lower Dark Hollow and reaches the Rose River fire road after 0.9 mile of climbing.\r\n\nWhen you reach the fire road, turn right and cross the bridge, where to your left is a long, narrow waterfall which descends from Dark Hollow Falls. Thirty yards beyond the bridge, the blue-blazed Dark Hollow Falls Trail goes uphill on the left. If you make a side trip to the base of these falls you'll add 0.3 mile and 145 feet of climbing to your trip.\r\n\nContinue uphill on the fire road back to Fishers Gap Overlook, about 1.1 miles from the bridge.\r\n\nThanks to Larry W. Brown, for sharing this trail description. {"url": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/7012228/whiteoak-canyon", "title": "Whiteoak Canyon", "difficulty": "Intermediate/Difficult", "trailhead": "https://maps.google.com/?daddr=38.585888,-78.382886", "gpx": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/gpx/7012228", "info-text": {"description": "Whiteoak Canyon is true wilderness beauty - a shady place of great boulders, of cascades and pools and sheer rock walls, and a steep gorge with 6 waterfalls. As you might expect, this has always been one of the most popular places in Shenandoah. On summer weekends you'll find the parking area full and the canyon crowded.\r\n\nThe trail, from the Skyline Drive to the first (and tallest) waterfall, is in good condition, and rather easy. But further down it gets steeper, and parts of it are rough and rocky. Please note that, like most waterfall trails starting from the Skyline Drive, you have an easy downhill jaunt, but the work comes on the way back up to your starting point. Remember when you descend into the canyon, you still have to work your way back up.\r\n\nThe trail starts gently downhill, swinging first right and then left around a swampy area. Cross a small stream and, 0.6 mile from the start, cross the Old Rag Fire Road. After another quarter of a mile you'll cross the Limberlost Accessible Trail. After a couple of hundred yards a small stream comes in from the right and flows beside the trail. \r\n\nContinue, downward. Pass cascades and pools, cliffs and ledges and surrealistic boulders. Then, a mile and a third from the Limberlost Trail, you come to another trail junction with a concrete marker post. The trail turns left here, crosses the stream on a bridge, and then continues downstream on the left bank to where the trail widens. 30 yards farther, a horse trail comes in on the left, and the Whiteoak Fire Road to the right. Continue straight ahead to another widening in the trail. Diagonally ahead to the right are two rocky ledges. From the downstream ledge you have a fine view of the upper falls.\r\n\nContinue, downward. Below the upper falls the canyon is narrow, and the trail is steep and rough. If you take the Whiteoak Canyon Trail all the way to the bottom, you'll reach a parking area in Berry Hollow, where most folks begin the Whiteoak Canyon to Cedar Run Loop. You can opt to continue on to the Cedar Run Trail from here, which will take you back to your original starting point at Skyline Drive.\r\n\nThanks to Larry W. Brown, for sharing this trail description. If you're interested in learning more details about great hikes, weather, camping / lodging, wildlife, and scenic drives, check out  snp.guide/.", "features": "River/Creek \u00b7 Swimming \u00b7 Views \u00b7 Waterfall \u00b7 Wildflowers \u00b7 Wildlife", "condition": "All Clear"}, "photo": "https://www.hikingproject.com/photo/7017404/the-second-of-6-waterfalls-in-whiteoak-canyon-the-1st-being-the-very-upper-falls", "ratings": {"rating": 4.6, "num_reviewers": 25}, "stats": {"dist": 5.0, "dist-type": "Point to Point", "alt-range": [3524, 1192], "alt-change": [3, 2335], "avg-grade": 9.0, "max-grade": 29.0}},

Access to the retreat is from Camp Hoover Road which is located just off Rapidan Road.\r\n\nThe lower section of Rapidan Road ends in Madison County (Criglersville) at VA Rt.649. It is open to public motor vehicle traffic and provides access to only a portion of the park, as well as the Rapidan State Wildlife Management Area, Rapidan Camps, Inc. (a private camp along the road), and a hiker/equestrian trailhead below the former Presidential Retreat.\r\n\nThanks to Larry W. Brown, for sharing this trail description. {"url": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/7011939/brown-mountain-trail", "title": "Brown Mountain Trail", "difficulty": "Difficult", "trailhead": "https://maps.google.com/?daddr=38.292648,-78.658013", "gpx": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/gpx/7011939", "info-text": {"description": "This trail starts from the break in the wall at the Brown Mountain Overlook. It starts descending fairly steeply following the ridge line to the north and west. As the trail begins to level out, look for the blue-blazed Rocky Mountain Run Trail that heads off to the left of the trail. \r\n\nFrom this point, the trail begins to ascend, gradually at first and then fairly strenuously, switchbacking up the ridge to the saddle close to the high points. Look for some brief but rewarding views of the Blue Ridge through breaks in the trees along this top stretch. The higher the trail gets, the more dispersed the trees and vegetation become, making for better views along the saddle. \r\n\nContinuing further, the trail gradually dips between the two summits of Rocky Mountain and then levels out. As you begin to ascend again, look to the ridge crest on the left. When views of the sky begin to peak between the base of the trees, you've reached the best view of this trail. Stroll over to the ridge crest at the top of a talus slope. Here, you can see back to the Blue Ridge and Skyline Drive where the trail began. \r\n\nThe trail continues along the edge of the ridge, almost entirely downward, with some fairly steep sections to be careful of. A few tight, downward switchbacks will mark the final half mile left before the trail ends at the Big Run Portal Trail.\r\n\nThanks to Larry W. Brown, for sharing this trail description. {"url": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/7011956/austin-mountain-trail", "title": "Austin Mountain Trail", "difficulty": "Difficult", "trailhead": "https://maps.google.com/?daddr=38.255017,-78.757592", "gpx": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/gpx/7011956", "info-text": {"description": "This trail starts in on the valley floor during the beginning of the Madison Run Road. When you encounter the cement post on the left side of the trail you'll begin a steep ascent up a side valley. The trail will continue to steepen as you head back west on the way to the ridge. Prior to reaching the crest of the ridge, the trail will bend back to the east and you'll have to traverse a few \"rock forests\" as the trail continues just under the south side of the ridge line. \r\n\nOnce the trail reaches the ridge line, the going gets easier as the trail transitions from strictly an uphill affair to a somewhat gentile up and down following of the ridge. During the following of the ridge, you'll cross the beginning of the Rockytop Trail. After the trail junction, you'll continue shortly on the north side of the ridge and then switch back to the south side and top side. \r\n\nAfter completing 3.2 miles you'll come to the junction of the Big Run Loop Trail and the Madison Run Spur Trail. If you use the spur trail, it returns you to the Madison Run Road and you can complete the 9.4 mile loop back to the parking area at the bottom of the valley.", "condition": "Unknown"}, "photo": "https://www.hikingproject.com/photo/7056457/rock-forest-trail-on-austin-ridge", "ratings": {"rating": 3.3, "num_reviewers": 4}, "stats": {"dist": 3.2, "dist-type": "Point to Point", "alt-range": [2758, 1487], "alt-change": [1392, 121], "avg-grade": 9.0, "max-grade": 26.0}},

{"url": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/7012021/furnace-mountain-trail", "title": "Furnace Mountain Trail", "difficulty": "Intermediate/Difficult", "trailhead": "https://maps.google.com/?daddr=38.256949,-78.769162", "gpx": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/gpx/7012021", "info-text": {"description": "This steep 3.3-mile ridge trail leads from the valley floor to the Trayfoot Mountain Trail. Access can be found at the end of VA663 with a few parking spots on the side of the dirt road at the turnaround area. If you venture with your vehicle down the road when it squeezes down to one lane, you'll be forced to back up the entire way to the turnaround area. \r\n\nFrom the parking area, hike a short distance up the Madison Run Road to a cement post that will point you to the right and across the creek. The trail doesn't waste any time getting to the uphill part. After following the ridgeline for about a mile and a half, you'll encounter another cement trail marker that provides directions to the Furnace Mtn Summit Trail. The summit is only a 0.5 mile detour, and the views to the northeast are will worth the deviation. \r\n\nAfter the detour, the trail continues up the ridge and some switchbacks for another 1.5 miles until it reaches its end at the junction with Trayfoot Mountain Trail. \r\n\nYou can make this a loop trail by heading east on the Trayfoot Mountain Trail to the AT, head north on the AT, then west down the Madison Run Road back to your car. This loop and access to all of these trails can be gained at the Black Rock Parking or Browns Gap Parking areas.", "features": "Birding \u00b7 Fall Colors \u00b7 River/Creek \u00b7 Views \u00b7 Wildflowers \u00b7 Wildlife", "condition": "All Clear"}, "photo": "https://www.hikingproject.com/photo/7027242/expect-to-find-this-marker-for-the-furnace-mountain-trail-if-accessing-it-from-s", "ratings": {"rating": 3.7, "num_reviewers": 6}, "stats": {"dist": 3.3, "dist-type": "Point to Point", "alt-range": [3232, 1411], "alt-change": [1866, 45], "avg-grade": 11.0, "max-grade": 26.0}},

After about a mile of easy hiking, you'll start to climb a bit more steeply as the trail turns further north and west to connect back with the Rocky Mount Trail. \r\n\nThe last mile is a steep and challenging climb to connect back to Rocky Mount Trail. {"url": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/7087824/asmussens-crack", "title": "Asmussen's Crack", "difficulty": "Very Difficult", "trailhead": "https://maps.google.com/?daddr=38.536802,-78.359404", "gpx": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/gpx/7087824", "info-text": {"description": "This old trail is blazed dark red on the trees. It is a boulder hop up from where the Cedar Run Trail crosses the stream and begins to switchback up the hill. This trail follows the stream and takes you to the base of the lower falls. After rock-hopping for the first bit of trail, it continues up the right hand side (facing down stream) of the stream all the way to the falls. There is a nice swimming hold at the base of the falls that is relatively private. Once at the lower falls, you can reverse back down to the beginning of the trail, or scrabble, climb up a ravine / crack in the rocky hillside. It is a strenuous climb that is named for a local trail guide, Michael Asmussen, who regularly followed this route while other mere mortals took the main trail. Amazed guests were heard to say, \"Look at him climbing up that crack in the rock, it is like he is a spider-monkey.\"", "features": "Fishing \u00b7 River/Creek \u00b7 Swimming \u00b7 Waterfall", "condition": "Unknown"}, "photo": "https://www.hikingproject.com/photo/7013859/lower-cedar-run-falls", "ratings": {"rating": 2.5, "num_reviewers": 2}, "stats": {"dist": 0.1, "dist-type": "Point to Point", "alt-range": [1552, 1456], "alt-change": [96, 0], "avg-grade": 14.0, "max-grade": 34.0}},
{"url": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/7102745/lewis-falls-loop-hike", "title": "Lewis Falls Loop Hike", "difficulty": "Intermediate", "trailhead": "https://maps.google.com/?daddr=38.5309,-78.439705", "gpx": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/gpx/7102745", "info-text": {"description": "This loop hike starts from the AT access trailhead to the left of the Amphitheater at the back of the Big Meadows picnic area, where there is plenty of parking.  Turn left on the AT, then immediately fork to the right on to Lewis Falls Trail.  This begins a long descent, first on dirt/gravel trail, but becoming more and more rocky as you approach the Lewis Falls area.  Carefully climb over several rocks (could be slippery/dangerous if wet) before reaching a post marking the junction with the Lewis Spring Falls Spur Trail.  Note the return route to the left to be taken later, but for now continue straight to the Lewis Falls viewing area at the top of the falls, marked by a large warning sign.  From here you can only see the stream coming into the top of the falls. But there's more!  \r\n\nTo the left of the sign, go upstream a few steps, cross the stream past a post with a sign warning not to drink the water, and head down a short, steep, rocky trail notable for a sturdy steel pipe railing, hanging on to prevent falling.  At the end of the steel pipe you reach the lower viewing area.  This observation area is bounded by a  circular stone wall, where you can start to get a decent view of the falls.  You cannot see all the way to the bottom of the falls due to overgrowth, but the view of the upper portion is worth the effort.  This is a good spot to relax and have a snack before beginning the uphill journey back.\r\n\nRetrace your way back up the spur trail to the first post noted above, and take the sharp right turn on the Lewis Falls Trail, heading up the hill.  After several switchbacks, there is a fake left turn, but head up to the right, then turn left on the AT.  Follow the AT back to the access trail, going uphill past a spectacular viewpoint, then downhill, passing the beginning of the Lewis Falls Trail on the left, then turning right on the access trail back to the parking lot by the Amphitheatre.\r\n\nLewis Falls has a reputation for not having much flow during dry seasons.", "features": "Views \u00b7 Waterfall", "condition": "Unknown"}, "photo": "https://www.hikingproject.com/photo/7013979/winter-view-of-lewis-spring-falls-as-seen-from-the-viewing-platform", "ratings": {"rating": 3.3, "num_reviewers": 3}, "stats": {"dist": 3.2, "dist-type": "Loop", "alt-range": [3669, 2831], "alt-change": [1015, 1027], "avg-grade": 12.0, "max-grade": 36.0}},

{"url": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/7012082/lewis-run-fire-road", "title": "Lewis Run Fire Road", "difficulty": "Intermediate", "trailhead": "https://maps.google.com/?daddr=38.302567,-78.737038", "gpx": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/gpx/7012082", "info-text": {"description": "Shenandoah National Park has over 500 miles of trails and roads for visitors to enjoy on foot or horseback. This is one of several old and seldom-used fire roads in the park that was built by the Civilian Conservation Corps. \r\n\nThe Civilian Conservation Corps was a part of President Franklin Roosevelt's New-Deal program. From 1933-1942, thousands of young men lived and worked in CCC camps in and adjacent to the park. The \"boys\" built rock walls, trails, fire roads, log structures, scenic overlooks, and more. They planted hundreds of thousands of trees and shrubs and are responsible for much of what visitors to Shenandoah see today. This year marks the 75th anniversary of the work of the CCC boys in Shenandoah National Park\r\n\nThese routes can range in grade, tread, and length and are often used on loops or as connections to more popular singletrack trails. For more information on a specific horse trail or access road, please visit the Shenandoah National Park website or call (540) 999-3500.", "features": "Birding \u00b7 Fall Colors \u00b7 River/Creek \u00b7 Wildlife", "condition": "Unknown"}, "ratings": {"rating": 2.0, "num_reviewers": 1}, "stats": {"dist": 1.0, "dist-type": "Point to Point", "alt-range": [1442, 1305], "alt-change": [72, 144], "avg-grade": 4.0, "max-grade": 14.0}},
{"url": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/7012097/jones-run-trail", "title": "Jones Run Trail", "difficulty": "Intermediate", "trailhead": "https://maps.google.com/?daddr=38.229942,-78.726124", "gpx": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/gpx/7012097", "info-text": {"description": "This gentle to moderate descent leads visitors through a bit of natural history. Since the area that is now Shenandoah National Park used to be pasture land, visitors will be able to descend through young forests, cross creeks and enjoy this shady trail on their way to the falls.\r\n\nThe Appalachian Trail (AT) crosses the Jones Run Trail just a few yards from its start. Cross the AT and, after about half a mile, cross Jones Run. The trail follows an old road trace for another third of a mile, then swings left and continues downhill through a very young forest that was a pasture when the park was created. After joining the stream on your left, continue another 0.2 mile to the head of the falls. \r\n\nThe trail swings sharp right, then makes a switchback to the left and returns to the base of the falls where there is a concrete marker post. Jones Run drops about 42 feet over a nearly vertical cliff that crosses the gorge and continues for a distance down the left bank of the stream. Where the cliff is watered by spray from the falls, it's covered with a great variety of mosses and flowering plants. \r\n\nReturn by the way you came, or you can opt to access the Doyles River Trail.\r\n\nThanks to Larry W. Brown, for sharing this trail description. {"url": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/7012121/big-run-loop-trail", "title": "Big Run Loop Trail", "difficulty": "Intermediate/Difficult", "trailhead": "https://maps.google.com/?daddr=38.25369,-78.684334", "gpx": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/gpx/7012121", "info-text": {"description": "The trail starts from Skyline Drive at the Big Run Overlook and descends by switchbacks. After two-thirds of a mile, it switches back sharply to the left and swings around a branch of Eppert Hollow. In the winter with the leaves off the trees, there are views across the hollow to Patterson Ridge, about a mile away, with parts of Rocky Mountain and Brown Mountain visible beyond it. The trail reaches a ridge crest at 1.2 miles, descends along the crest, and then levels off. (In spring, look for dwarf Iris here.) After a final switchback to the left, the trail crosses a stream. There are some very large trees here, and the forest is open and spacious.\r\n\nContinuing on the trail, you'll come to a fork where you'll want to take a left to stay on the Big Run Loop Trail. The trail branching to the right heads down to Big Run. After about 1.3 miles, you'll reach a trail crossing on the ridge crest. (The trail ahead descends 0.3 mile to the Madison Run fire road. The Rockytop Trail, to the right, goes to the lower end of Big Run.) Turn left, and the trail continues to climb the crest of the Blue Ridge before a short descent to its end point at the AT.\r\n\nThanks to Larry W. Brown, for sharing this trail description. {"url": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/7012123/paine-run-trail", "title": "Paine Run Trail", "difficulty": "Intermediate", "trailhead": "https://maps.google.com/?daddr=38.206602,-78.749776", "gpx": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/gpx/7012123", "info-text": {"description": "The trailhead for Paine Run Trail is located on the west side of Skyline Drive. The Paine Run Trail heads south and west to the park boundary, where it joins SRs 614 and 661.  \r\n\nAbout a mile down the Paine Run Trail is Blackrock Springs, which was a fashionable resort with a hotel, cabins, recreation hall, and bowling alley. The resort reached the height of its popularity in the 1840s and 1850s. It burned down early in the last century. The waters of Blackrock Springs were said to be good for whatever ails you. According to advertisements, they contained iron, soda, lime, magnesia, and carbonic acid gas. When Mme. Curie discovered radium, that too was added to the list of ingredients. There were seven springs of different colors and different healing properties, including one for arthritis, one for rheumatism, one for gout, and one for aiding the growth of hair. If you'd like to see where the hotel once stood or if you're suffering from a shortage of hair or other ailments, you should definitely take the time to explore Blackrock Springs. \r\n\nContinuing your hike on the Pain Run Trail will have you paralleling Paine Run as you descend gradually and steadily toward the edge of the park. Shortly before the trail ends you'll come across the junction with the Trayfoot Mountain Trail which branches off to the north.\r\n\nThanks to Larry W. Brown, for sharing this trail description. If you\u2019re interested in learning more details about great hikes, weather, camping / lodging, wildlife, and scenic drives, check out the comprehensive Guide to Shenandoah National Park.", "features": "River/Creek \u00b7 Wildflowers \u00b7 Wildlife", "condition": "Unknown"}, "photo": "https://www.hikingproject.com/photo/7040692/off-season-in-the-shenandoah-is-heavenly-low-temperature-camping-off-the-paine-r", "ratings": {"rating": 3.0, "num_reviewers": 6}, "stats": {"dist": 3.7, "dist-type": "Point to Point", "alt-range": [2343, 1464], "alt-change": [11, 891], "avg-grade": 5.0, "max-grade": 15.0}},
{"url": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/7012140/madison-run-road", "title": "Madison Run Road", "difficulty": "Intermediate", "trailhead": "https://maps.google.com/?daddr=38.24085,-78.71123", "gpx": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/gpx/7012140", "info-text": {"description": "Madison Run was named for a wealthy settler who, in about 1750, built an estate called Madison Hall near its mouth.\r\n\nAround the same time, Benjamin Brown and his son, also Benjamin Brown, started to purchase land around the western part of Albemarle County. This included more than 6,000 acres on both sides of what is now Doyles River. With these properties, the Browns became one of the most important families in that part of the county. \r\n\nIn 1805, Brightberry Brown (a son/grandson of Benjamin Brown) and William Jarman built a turnpike road across the Blue Ridge (hence Browns Gap). For a number of years, this road was one of the major routes between the Shenandoah Valley and Richmond to bring produce and goods back and forth.\r\n\nThe turnpike has now become a park fire road. This section, Madison Run Road, heads down the west side, off Skyline Drive at Browns Gap. The route descends around five miles to the park boundary, where the road becomes SR 663. This lower end of the Madison Run hollow is worth exploring for visitors who have the time and fitness level for this longer distance.\r\n\nThanks to Larry W. Brown, for sharing this trail description. {"url": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/7012149/rockytop-trail", "title": "Rockytop Trail", "difficulty": "Difficult", "trailhead": "https://maps.google.com/?daddr=38.251108,-78.714428", "gpx": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/gpx/7012149", "info-text": {"description": "To access this trail, use the parking area at Browns Gap and head north on the white-blazed AT for around a half mile. Look for the Big Run Loop Trail heading off to the left. Take this blue-blazed trail for two-thirds of a mile until the junction with and start of the Rockytop Trail. \r\n\nStart on the trail as it heads gradually uphill and then dips downhill near the junction with the Austin Mountain Trail. Continue right at the fork to stay on this trail as it bends northward keeping a fairly level and manageable grade. \r\n\nOnce the trail passes the Lewis Peak Trail, it begins to descend along the ridge line toward the locally acknowledge Rockytop Peak. The trail skirts around the west side of the peak, switchbacking up toward the talus slopes above. \r\n\nFrom the north side of the peak, the trail begins to descend along the ridge with a few switchbacks ending at the Big Run Portal Trail.\r\n\nThanks to Larry W. {"url": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/7012156/rocky-mount-trail", "title": "Rocky Mount Trail", "difficulty": "Difficult", "trailhead": "https://maps.google.com/?daddr=38.299155,-78.64709", "gpx": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/gpx/7012156", "info-text": {"description": "This is a tough hike; near the summit, the trail is steep and rough and there is a lot of elevation change. But if you are looking for a trail that gives you some good exercise and rewards you with solitude and a great view, this is the trail for you! \r\n\nThe Rocky Mount Trail starts by descending rather steeply then more gradually. From a low point at about 0.6 mile from the start, the trail skirts the left side of a low knob. During the winter, there are views to your left, toward Two Mile Ridge. In the summer, the views tend to be obscured by foliage. (In spring, look for the pink flowers of fringed Polygala and in the summer for the purple flowers of the Go Rue beside the trail.) \r\n\nDon't be fooled by this initial descent as the trail then starts to climb in earnest. The trail ascends, passing to the right of a knob and then descending for 0.9 mile to a gap, where the Gap Run Trail (named for a different gap, not this one) comes in on the right, about 2.2 miles from the trailhead.\r\n\nFrom the gap, the trail climbs nearly a thousand feet in 1.2 miles, with switchbacks, up the south side of Rocky Mount. In winter, but not in summer, there are occasional good views across Two Mile Run to Two Mile Ridge. A few yards short of the summit is your destination. From there you can climb to a rock with a fine view of Two Mile Ridge to Rocky Mountain and, farther left, to the Blue Ridge and a part of Skyline Drive and enjoy your well-earned views.\r\n\nFrom the summit, the trail continues on a steady descent along the ridge to its junction with the Gap Run Trail near Gap Run. This section is through the trees so don't expect the same quality of views as you enjoyed at the summit of Rocky Mount.\r\n\nThanks to Larry W. Brown, for sharing this trail description. If you\u2019re interested in learning more details about great hikes, weather, camping / lodging, wildlife, and scenic drives, check out the comprehensive Guide to Shenandoah National Park.", "features": "Fall Colors \u00b7 Views \u00b7 Wildflowers", "condition": "Minor Issues"}, "photo": "https://www.hikingproject.com/photo/7010517/looking-south-from-rocky-mount-in-shenandoah-national-park", "ratings": {"rating": 3.5, "num_reviewers": 8}, "stats": {"dist": 5.3, "dist-type": "Point to Point", "alt-range": [2753, 1284], "alt-change": [839, 2309], "avg-grade": 11.0, "max-grade": 30.0}},

{"url": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/7012178/riprap-trail", "title": "Riprap Trail", "difficulty": "Intermediate", "trailhead": "https://maps.google.com/?daddr=38.182542,-78.761975", "gpx": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/gpx/7012178", "info-text": {"description": "To access the blue-blazed Riprap Trail, head uphill from the Riprap Trailhead parking area and turn right onto the white-blazed AT: Potomac Appalachian Trail Club (PA/MD/VA/WV). About four-tenths of a mile from the start, look for a left turn onto the Riprap Trail. It continues along generally descending to a talus slope that crosses the ridge. The trail bends to the right, then swings left with a number of white rocks on the right that mark the Paine Run watershed down below. \r\n\nThe rock tower ahead is Chimney Rock. In front of you, Trayfoot Mountain bounds the far side of the hollow. The trail continues to Chimney Rock.\r\n\nFrom Chimney Rock, after around three-quarters of a mile, the trail bends to the left and begins to drop into Cold Spring Hollow. A little more than a mile further and a stream merges in from the left, and the trail joins Riprap Hollow. One hundred feet downstream is a small but very picturesque cascade.\r\n\nThe trail crosses the stream and continues for another hundred yards until a side trail heads off to the right, crossing the stream toward the Riprap Shelter site, which is next to one of the biggest swimming holes in the park. The Riprap Shelter no longer exists, as it was removed when the area became a wilderness. From the shelter site, you can continue downstream for a couple hundred feet to merge back onto the trail. \r\n\nA short distance ahead the trail forks. Bear right, heading along the relocated trail as it stays on higher ground that avoids flood damage. The trail continues for another half-mile or so until the intersection with the Wildcat Ridge Trail. The Riprap Trail continues for three-quarters of a mile to the western limit of the park.\r\n\nThanks to Larry W. Brown, for sharing this trail description. {"url": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/7012179/simmons-gap-road", "title": "Simmons Gap Road", "difficulty": "Intermediate", "trailhead": "https://maps.google.com/?daddr=38.316425,-78.6288", "gpx": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/gpx/7012179", "info-text": {"description": "Shenandoah National Park has over 500 miles of trails and roads for visitors to enjoy on foot or horseback. This is one of several old and seldom-used fire roads in the park that was built by the Civilian Conservation Corps. \r\n\nThe Civilian Conservation Corps was a part of President Franklin Roosevelt's New-Deal program. From 1933 -1942, thousands of young men lived and worked in CCC camps in and adjacent to the park. The \"boys\" built rock walls, trails, fire roads, log structures, scenic overlooks, and more. They planted hundreds of thousands of trees and shrubs and are responsible for much of what visitors to Shenandoah see today. This year marks the 75th anniversary of the work of the CCC in Shenandoah National Park.\r\n\nThese routes range in grade, tread, and length and are often used on loops or as connections to more popular singletrack trails. For more information on a specific horse trail or access road, please visit the Shenandoah National Park website or call (540) 999-3500.", "features": "Birding \u00b7 Fall Colors \u00b7 River/Creek \u00b7 Spring \u00b7 Views", "condition": "All Clear"}, "ratings": {"rating": 2.0, "num_reviewers": 1}, "stats": {"dist": 2.5, "dist-type": "Point to Point", "alt-range": [2274, 1813], "alt-change": [492, 245], "avg-grade": 6.0, "max-grade": 11.0}},

{"url": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/7012217/trayfoot-mountain-trail", "title": "Trayfoot Mountain Trail", "difficulty": "Intermediate/Difficult", "trailhead": "https://maps.google.com/?daddr=38.19811,-78.789167", "gpx": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/gpx/7012217", "info-text": {"description": "This incredible ridgeline climb begins at the junction of Paine Run Trail near its western terminus. A couple of switchbacks will lead you up to the beginning of the ridge. Once on the ridge, the trail follows it north while jumping back and forth between the west and east sides. The views from either side are spectacular in the late fall. \r\n\nThe ascent of the ridge is relentless with only a couple sections of switchbacks and even fewer level spots.  The trail starts in the valley at around 1,500 feet and the summit of Mt. Tray foot is at around 3,300 feet. You'll reach the peak around the 3.7-mile marker where the trail finally starts to head downhill. The views from the summit may be diminished by tree leaves during spring and summer seasons. \r\n\nAs the trail heads back down, it will cross the trailhead of the Furnace Mountain Trail. The trail will terminate along the base of the Blackrock Peak access. Hikers can either take the Blackrock Spur Trail to the peak or continue around the base to the end of this trail at the connector trail that leads to either the Blackrock Parking lot to the north or the Blackrock Gap Parking lot to the south.", "features": "Birding \u00b7 Fall Colors \u00b7 Views \u00b7 Wildflowers \u00b7 Wildlife", "condition": "Unknown"}, "photo": "https://www.hikingproject.com/photo/7085436/looking-up-the-rock-pile-to-blackrock-from-the-viewpoint-on-trayfoot-mountain-tr", "ratings": {"rating": 4.2, "num_reviewers": 6}, "stats": {"dist": 4.8, "dist-type": "Point to Point", "alt-range": [3377, 1505], "alt-change": [1976, 485], "avg-grade": 10.0, "max-grade": 33.0}},

{"url": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/7012235/doyles-river-trail", "title": "Doyles River Trail", "difficulty": "Intermediate/Difficult", "trailhead": "https://maps.google.com/?daddr=38.254226,-78.682924", "gpx": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/gpx/7012235", "info-text": {"description": "Take the Doyles River Trail downhill from the parking area. Cross the Appalachian Trail (AT) and descend rather steeply for 0.3 mile to an unprotected spring that flows from a pipe in a stone wall on the left. Do not use the water without effective treatment. Just beyond the spring, the trail forks. The left fork climbs rather steeply for 400 feet to the locked Doyles River Cabin. Keep right, and continue about 0.6 mile to the Browns Gap Road. \r\n\nCross the road and continue on the Doyles River Trail, which crosses the Doyles River after 250 yards. Go another 300 yards. Here, as the trail begins to turn right, the top of the falls is about 25 feet to your left; but you can't see the falls from the top. Follow the trail to the right, away from the falls. It swings left in a wide 180-degree curve to a low point with a marker post. The falls are in sight to your left, in a natural amphitheater, surrounded by giant trees. It's a beautiful sight to see.\r\n\nContinue downhill on the trail, through a narrow gorge with the stream downhill on your left. The sides of the gorge rise steeply, and you pass some of the biggest trees in the park. The top of the lower falls is 0.3 mile from the concrete marker near the upper falls. A short side trail on the left goes to the top of the falls.\r\n\nFollow the trail to the right, away from the falls. Continue fifty yards more and the trail takes a sharp switchback to the left on a slippery slanting rock. Then back through poison ivy and down to the base of the falls, mostly hidden by trees. Fifty yards farther, at a concrete marker, a very rough and rocky side trail on the left goes back to the base of the falls.\r\n\nAbout 0.2 mile farther down the gorge cross a small stream, on a footbridge, with a cascade just to the right of the trail. From there it's 0.4 mile to a marker post at the low point of your hike. Here you can opt to get on the Jones Run Trail, which swings right and starts uphill beside Jones Run. Where the trail crosses the stream, note the big sycamore 60 feet to your left. It shows how far down you've come; in Shenandoah, sycamores grow only at lower altitudes.\r\n\nThanks to Larry W. Brown, for sharing this trail description.
