{"url": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/7036786/butternut-trail", "title": "Butternut Trail", "difficulty": "Difficult", "trailhead": "https://maps.google.com/?daddr=37.316956,-80.79356", "gpx": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/gpx/7036786", "info-text": {"description": "The Butternut Trail (unblazed as of 9/2017) starts from the Mill Creek Nature Park parking area. The trail heads south along Mill Creek (do not cross the footbridge). There are some unmarked trails that shoot off, but you'll be staying on the main trail near the creek. \r\n\nAfter approximately 0.4 miles, you'll come to a small camping shelter and a small reservoir behind a dam (the dam was constructed with hand-cut stones in the 1780s and is still functional more than 200 years later).  Just past the shelter, you'll see a sign for the Butternut Trail heading uphill and to the left. Take this and let the climbing begin.  \r\n\nThe trail has many loose rocks and gets STEEP, especially just before the intersection with the Catwalk Trail at approximately 0.8 miles. After the intersection with the signed Catwalk Trail, continue up and up along the steep switchbacked logging road; at times the trail becomes a singletrack. Eventually, the gradient levels off before a junction with the signed Rocky Ridge Trail after approximately 1.8 miles. \r\n\nThe trail crosses the Mercy Branch and comes to a junction with the signed Mercy Branch Trail in another tenth of a mile. Continue downhill along the Butternut Trail past a junction with the signed Old Rhodie Trail.  Butternut continues along at a moderate grade through rhododendron tunnels until its terminus at the signed junction with Piney Road Trail and Catwalk Trail. To return to the parking area, take the steep Catwalk Trail to the right which will eventually take you to the Waterfalls Trail and past four waterfalls.\r\n\nBe sure to dress in bright colors during hunting season (generally fall and winter). The town of Narrows and nearby Pearisburg both have many trails and are investing in outdoor recreation. Stop in at local restaurants and stores to support these small towns so they continue to encourage outdoor recreation!", "features": "Birding \u00b7 Fall Colors \u00b7 River/Creek \u00b7 Swimming \u00b7 Views \u00b7 Wildlife", "condition": "Unknown"}, "photo": "https://www.hikingproject.com/photo/7037083/looking-down-the-moss-covered-rocks-of-mill-creek-from-the-footbridge", "ratings": {"rating": 2.0, "num_reviewers": 1}, "stats": {"dist": 2.7, "dist-type": "Point to Point", "alt-range": [3142, 1905], "alt-change": [1252, 253], "avg-grade": 10.0, "max-grade": 33.0}},
{"url": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/7036792/catwalk-trail", "title": "Catwalk Trail", "difficulty": "Difficult", "trailhead": "https://maps.google.com/?daddr=37.307547,-80.793408", "gpx": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/gpx/7036792", "info-text": {"description": "To reach the Catwalk Trail from the Mill Creek Nature Park parking area in Narrows, you must either ascend the Waterfalls Trail or Butternut Trail. The Catwalk Trail descends to a junction with the Waterfall Trail on the right or continuing up the Catwalk Trail to the left (south). \r\n\nThe Catwalk Trail changes its character dramatically and the gradient gets steep and has multiple rock gardens to pick your way through. There are two waterfalls along Mill Creek where you can take steep spur trails down to along the southern portion of the Catwalk Trail. The Catwalk Trail ends after a steep ascent up to a junction with the Butternut Trail to the left (east) (you can take this to form a loop back to the parking area) and the Piney Road Trail to the right (west).  \r\n\nBe sure to dress in bright colors during hunting season (generally fall and winter). {"url": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/7036809/mercy-branch-trail", "title": "Mercy Branch Trail", "difficulty": "Intermediate", "trailhead": "https://maps.google.com/?daddr=37.301452,-80.78579", "gpx": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/gpx/7036809", "info-text": {"description": "The Mercy Branch Trail is a great trail accessible from the Mill Creek Nature Park parking area; it just takes some work to reach it. You can reach the Mercy Branch Trail by ascending the steep Butternut Trail for approximately 1.9 miles.  Just after you pass the signed Rocky Ridge Trail, you'll pass over the trickling creek that makes up Mercy Branch and the signed Mercy Branch trailhead is a couple hundred feet after the creek.  \r\n\nThe trail climbs slowly, often on a soft pine needle surface and often within a rhododendron tunnel. Towards the northeastern-most point on the trail in the last 1/4 mile, you'll start to see orange blazes which will take you to the signed and orange-blazed Rocky Ridge Trail. Mercy Branch can be taken as an out-and-back or as a loop combined with the Rocky Ridge Trail. Traveling counterclockwise (going up Mercy Branch and down Rocky Ridge) keeps the steepest parts of the loop as downhills.  \r\n\nBe sure to dress in bright colors during hunting season (generally fall and winter). The town of Narrows and nearby Pearisburg both have many trails and are investing in outdoor recreation. {"url": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/7036853/rocky-ridge-trail", "title": "Rocky Ridge Trail", "difficulty": "Intermediate", "trailhead": "https://maps.google.com/?daddr=37.314006,-80.764078", "gpx": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/gpx/7036853", "info-text": {"description": "The orange-blazed Rocky Ridge Trail completes a nice loop alongside with the unblazed (but signed and obvious) Mercy Branch Trail. Short spur trails to waterfalls are signed on the main trail. After approximately 0.5 miles on the Waterfalls Trail, you'll reach its southern terminus at an intersection with the Catwalk Trail. You can create a short lollipop loop back to your car by taking the Catwalk Trail to the left and taking another left to go down the Butternut Trail back to the parking lot.\r\n\nBe sure to dress in bright colors during hunting season (generally fall and winter). There are about ten spurs leading to the adjacent streets which makes this trail very accessible for anyone living in the neighborhoods nearby. The trail does have some short elevation gains and losses, so be aware of bikers picking up speed, and because of the high traffic, it is recommended to avoid using earbuds on this trail. {"url": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/7038008/cmhp-rr-service-road", "title": "CMHP RR Service Road", "difficulty": "Intermediate", "trailhead": "https://maps.google.com/?daddr=37.187227,-80.427883", "gpx": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/gpx/7038008", "info-text": {"description": "Starting at the same parking lot as the Coal Mining Heritage Loop Trail near the Trash & Recycling Center, do not go down the boardwalk, and instead go to the left around the swinging gate. There is a constructed gap that runners, walkers, and bikers can fit through on the right side of the gate. \r\n\nThe dirt road is above and parallels the eastern half of the Coal Mining Heritage Loop Trail. It descends to the Huckleberry Trail about 150' south of where the Coal Mining Heritage Loop Trail crosses the Huckleberry. Look both ways to be sure to not collide with a biker at this crossing. \r\n\nThe dirt road continues across the Huckleberry Trail, rising, leveling out, and descending back to where it crosses over the Norfolk & Western Railroad tracks at 0.75 miles. This is the turn-around point for many hikers. Crossing over the tracks, the road gets continually less and less friendly for hikers (and you can get stuck waiting 10-15 minutes for the train to pass). The gravel gets larger and larger and more and more uncomfortable to hike on as you continue.  \r\n\nThe section between the first and second railroad crossings is okay, though. After the second RR crossing at 1.0 miles, the gravel gets more noticeable, and by the time the road is right next to the railroad, the gravel is more like large pointed rocks, making hiking uncomfortable for long distances. This is the other normal turn-around point for an out and back.\r\n\nTheoretically, this road goes for miles paralleling the tracks all the way to the New River and could someday become an awesome rails-to-trail project, but for now, it seems ill-advised to continue for anyone but people who are ok with potentially pointlessly injuring their feet.\r\n\nThis trail is a nice add-on to doing laps of the Coal Mining Heritage Loop Trail or in conjunction with hiking on the Huckleberry Trail.", "features": "Birding \u00b7 Fall Colors \u00b7 Wildlife", "condition": "Unknown"}, "photo": "https://www.hikingproject.com/photo/7040157/the-beautifully-constructed-boardwalk-at-the-entrance-to-cmhp", "ratings": {"rating": 2.0, "num_reviewers": 1}, "stats": {"dist": 1.3, "dist-type": "Point to Point", "alt-range": [2071, 1949], "alt-change": [91, 171], "avg-grade": 4.0, "max-grade": 10.0}},

{"url": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/7012120/north-fork-moormans-river-trail", "title": "North Fork Moorman's River Trail", "difficulty": "Intermediate", "trailhead": "https://maps.google.com/?daddr=38.13942,-78.749525", "gpx": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/gpx/7012120", "info-text": {"description": "If starting at the lower parking lot, begin by hiking .5 miles up the road to the trailhead. There is only room for a few cars in the immediate vicinity of the trailhead.\r\n\nAbout 0.4 miles into the hike, you arrive at the first creek crossing. While it is only an easy rock hop across in the late summer, plan to take off your shoes and ford it in April or May. The creek opens up into a large swimming hole to the left of the crossing. Cross the creek two more times shortly after this (these crossings are easier).  \r\n\nAbout 1.9 miles into the trail, Big Branch approaches from the left. To see Big Branch Falls, hike left before crossing Big Branch onto the Big Branch Falls Spur. The falls are very pretty in the spring, but amount to a little more than a trickle down a rock face later in the summer. Another small and shallow swimming hole is located immediately beneath the falls.  \r\n\nAfter returning from Big Branch Falls, cross Big Branch to continue on the trail. {"url": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/7012170/south-fork-moormans-river-road", "title": "South Fork Moormans River Road", "difficulty": "Easy/Intermediate", "trailhead": "https://maps.google.com/?daddr=38.138488,-78.748725", "gpx": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/gpx/7012170", "info-text": {"description": "The South Fork Moormans River Road starts from the northwest corner of the Charlottesville Reservoir off of Sugar Hollow Rd. There is a large gravel parking area for about ten cars. From the trailhead, the trail heads southwest through the woods following along the South Fork Moormans River. At times, you'll be close enough to the river to appreciate the scenic cascades. Overall, the path itself is wide and mostly smooth and the only challenge is the ever so slight incline along the way. {"url": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/7036158/lake-maury-right-trail", "title": "Lake Maury Right Trail", "difficulty": "Intermediate", "trailhead": "https://maps.google.com/?daddr=37.057754,-76.48268", "gpx": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/gpx/7036158", "info-text": {"description": "This is definitely one of the longer ways out to the end of the trail system without overlapping at all. It involves taking rights at every fork you come across, with the exception of those times it dumps out onto the access road.\r\n\nStart out heading down from the street side parking on Gatewood along the lake. You'll soon come to a fork, up or down; it doesn't matter which way you go, the trails meet up again shortly. You'll soon approach another fork, again either way will take you to about the same spot soon there after the access road.\r\n\nContinue straight down the access road - do not go across the road immediately, this is a dead end. After about 150 yards the road goes right, but the trail goes straight up a small hill. If you continue up this trail you'll be to the meat of the singletrack.\r\n\nThere are numerous possible routes to take through here. I've found if you take the right option when available you get the most track in without retracing your path. Again though, numerous possibilities are available.\r\n\nIn about the middle of this area there's a terrain park for the bikers.\r\n\nAfter the terrain park, continue across the bridge at the bottom and stay to the right. You'll come to an elevated singletrack section that traces around an area with lots of bamboo. This was clearly a man-made area, presumably from the initial creation of the reservoir. There are a few other biking features in this area and it's an interesting hike around and through the bamboo if you're interested. If not, keep going and you won't miss much.\r\n\nPast this, there's more singletrack winding through the woods until you come to the access road again to cross a small creek. You can either turn around or continue on to the other side. The mainstay of the area is behind you, but there's new ground ahead for mostly an out and back type.\r\n\nYou'll cross a couple of bridges and come up to street level a couple times, though always staying on the dirt/grass, and eventually ending up at a no biking sign. At this point you can either follow the trail to loop around or look for one of the few exits to head back via streets to your car. You'll undoubtedly retrace some of your steps if you loop back, but there are plenty of options to keep it new and different.", "condition": "Unknown"}, "ratings": {"rating": 4.0, "num_reviewers": 1}, "stats": {"dist": 4.7, "dist-type": "Point to Point", "alt-range": [33, 10], "alt-change": [296, 292], "avg-grade": 2.0, "max-grade": 5.0}},
{"url": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/7039421/dora-trail", "title": "Dora Trail", "difficulty": "Easy", "trailhead": "https://maps.google.com/?daddr=37.045595,-80.779385", "gpx": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/gpx/7039421", "info-text": {"description": "There are multiple access points to the Dora Trail, but the most popular is the free parking area in downtown Pulaski at the Pulaski Train Station and Kiwanis Park. Head east through Kiwanis Park and continue along the signed Dora Trail.   Stay on the main trail and please respect private property (the Dora Trail is adjacent to several backyards) and the property of the railroad.  \r\n\nAt 0.8 miles, the trail crosses the Dora Highway and switches from pavement to crushed stone. The trail quickly recrosses to the north side of the Dora Hwy and passes through Heritage Park. The trail winds alongside Peak Creek.  The only downside to the trail is when it passes beside Pulaski's Wastewater Treatment Plant, which sometimes gives off smells for a short distance. Quickly pass it by and travel under Hwy 99 and the New River Trail trestle to curve up and around to the Dora Trail's junction with the New River Trail after 2.5 miles.  \r\n\nTaking the New River Trail to the right takes you 0.5 miles to the northern terminus of the New River Trail State Park (there is also parking here for a small fee that supports the New River Trail State Park, which is worth supporting). Taking a left at the junction will quickly take you across the first of many trestles on the New River Trail and in the direction of the town of Draper and Galax 56+ miles away to the south.  \r\n\nThis is a multi-use trail with bikers and horses. Please check out  altamons.org/hiking.html to see when it is okay to use the trail.    \r\n\nPlease park at the parking area next to the bath house (on the right as you pull into the driveway). After passing by the field and house at the end of the field, follow the signs to the left at the junction with the Boy Scout Loop and Christmas Tree Mountain Trail. The trail becomes singletrack at this point and parallels Purgatory Creek to its end at Stiles Falls. The trail rock-hops across the creek three times before reaching the falls. {"url": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/7040995/ellett-valley-nature-trail-yellow", "title": "Ellett Valley Nature Trail (Yellow)", "difficulty": "Intermediate", "trailhead": "https://maps.google.com/?daddr=37.1883,-80.377407", "gpx": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/gpx/7040995", "info-text": {"description": "The yellow-blazed main loop of the Ellett Valley Nature Trail is accessed from a small parking lot on the south side of Jennelle Road. \r\n\nFrom the information board, ascend the stair-stepped slope, climbing up to the main loop. Traveling around the loop in a clockwise fashion has shorter climbs interspersed with flat stretches and a long steady downhill to finish it up. Going counter-clockwise gives a steady couple hundred foot ascent to train on. \r\n\nAs you proceed around the loop, there are many interpretive signs to acquaint you with the natural area. There are a few other social trails in the area, so look out for the yellow blazes to stay on trail and not enter private property or areas where hunting is legal.\r\n\nThis is a lightly-used gem protecting a swath of forest. There is no hunting allowed in Ellett Valley Nature Park, but the area to the west of the trail has multiple tree-stands, so dress in bright colors (including your dogs) during hunting season (generally October through January).", "features": "Birding \u00b7 Fall Colors \u00b7 Wildlife", "condition": "Unknown"}, "ratings": {"rating": 3.0, "num_reviewers": 2}, "stats": {"dist": 0.9, "dist-type": "Point to Point", "alt-range": [2026, 1764], "alt-change": [272, 187], "avg-grade": 10.0, "max-grade": 39.0}},

{"url": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/7045756/red-trail", "title": "Red Trail", "difficulty": "Intermediate", "trailhead": "https://maps.google.com/?daddr=38.673608,-77.171338", "gpx": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/gpx/7045756", "info-text": {"description": "This is a fairly easy four mile trail but the markers could be a little more frequent as they are a little confusing at times; check the GPS trail for help. You quickly pass a junction for the white trail which heads right; shortly after the Blue Trail splits and one section heads right, while the other continues along the Red Trail. After a bit, it splits off to the left and follows along the road and then behind some of the neighborhood before continuing off into the woods. After about 0.6 miles of hiking, the Red Trail splits to the left and right (the Blue Trail continues straight). \r\n\nAt this point there are some elevation changes as you hike down into the creek bed and then up the other side. Most of the trail winds through the trees. About two miles along the trail, you'll descend a hill which brings you to the lakeshore. This next section follows along the water and offers some nice views. There are also some fishing spots at this point. About 3.3 miles in the trail turns away from the lake and climbs a hill. Just after reaching the top of the hill you'll cross a junction with the Blue Trail. Continue south to where the Red Trail initially split. To get back your car turn left to head east and retrace your steps. \r\n\nBeing the longest trail in the park also generally makes it the least popular, and so we usually don't run into as many people. {"url": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/7036843/slab-town-trail", "title": "Slab Town Trail", "difficulty": "Intermediate/Difficult", "trailhead": "https://maps.google.com/?daddr=36.763321,-81.49289", "gpx": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/gpx/7036843", "info-text": {"description": "This is a lightly traveled trail that follows the old route of the AT. It has much to offer with lots of challenges along the way. Expect a lot of ups and downs and log crossings. Probably the best quality of this trail is how much solitude it offers.\r\n\nIt's lightly used today and can easily be lost in places due to infrequent maintenance. The trail starts with a steady climb from the valley floor. After a half-mile, its eases up but continues to climb to the top of the first ridge for one mile. \r\n\nThere, the trail descends along an old logging cut to cross over Slab Town Road. On the other side, it proceeds across a cow pasture before re-entering the forest. The next part of the climb begins, though not as steep as the first segment, to the top of the next ridge. You'll pass though old homesites and along an old stone walled road. Don't worry, it's still singletrack as none of these roads have been used in over 100 years. \r\n\nAt the 1.90-mile mark, the trail enters some old iron ore mine works that were abandoned 120 years ago. At 2.5 miles, the trail descends to its end at the Trempi shelter on the AT. There is a good source of water here that flows year round. Hikers can return the way they came, or transfer over to the Appalachian Trail for a nice loop.", "condition": "Unknown"}, "ratings": {"rating": 3.8, "num_reviewers": 4}, "stats": {"dist": 5.7, "dist-type": "Out and Back", "alt-range": [3135, 2490], "alt-change": [1208, 1208], "avg-grade": 8.0, "max-grade": 34.0}},

{"url": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/7029210/upper-hoop-hole-trail-5001", "title": "Upper Hoop Hole Trail (5001)", "difficulty": "Intermediate", "trailhead": "https://maps.google.com/?daddr=37.673056,-79.917631", "gpx": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/gpx/7029210", "info-text": {"description": "This route features a unique figure 8 type routing, with hikers completing two loops by the journey's end. Both loops offer beautiful views of the streams cascading over rocks and swimming holes. The longer loop climbs to the top of a ridge for scenic views of the surrounding mountains. One could try to reach certain cliffs from the ridgetop for more expanded views. The trail is very rugged and good footwear is almost required. Also, be very cautious as the trail is sometimes very difficult to see and the yellow blazes are sometime far apart.\r\n\n\nIf you need hiking supplies, Outdoor Trails on US 220 near the intersection with I-81 is a good option. Also any trip to this area is not complete without a trip to The Fountain sandwich grill in Ransone\u2019s Drug store in the town of Buchanan. Step back in time or if you prefer to treat yourself to some of Virginia\u2019s award-winning wines, the Botetourt County Wine Trail consists of three local wineries located along Rt. 220 which is only a few miles from Roaring Run.", "condition": "Unknown"}, "ratings": {"rating": 4.3, "num_reviewers": 3}, "stats": {"dist": 8.6, "dist-type": "Loop", "alt-range": [3312, 1374], "alt-change": [1972, 1963], "avg-grade": 9.0, "max-grade": 24.0}},

It is most popular among bikers, runners and birders. This trail starts at the end of smaller of the two parking areas. Approximately one quarter mile down the trail, stay to the left at the fork. Continue along the trail straight through the open white gate approximately one mile down the gravel path. If the gate is closed do not enter the East Dike Trail. \r\n\nOn this trail, visitors have views the refuge's impoundment system and the sand dunes. The impoundment system is comprised of man-made water pools which are managed to provide habitat to migratory birds throughout the year. Waterfowls (ducks, geese and swans) use this area during their winter migration. Shorebirds and wading birds are the primary residents during the spring and fall.", "features": "Birding \u00b7 Wildlife", "condition": "Unknown"}, "photo": "https://www.hikingproject.com/photo/7050683/start-of-dune-trail", "ratings": {"rating": 2.0, "num_reviewers": 3}, "stats": {"dist": 3.2, "dist-type": "Point to Point", "alt-range": [10, 3], "alt-change": [17, 16], "avg-grade": 0.0, "max-grade": 0.0}},

Witchback has more sustained climbs and longer descents than most trails at Angler's. Witchback can be connected with White Fawn and Hidden Hollow for the Orange Loop (15/16 mile loop). Make sure to stay on the outside if you want to hike the whole thing. In this counter-clockwise direction, there are two places earlier on where you have to stay to the right to avoid taking an early exit. After Graveyard Hill, you'll hang left at a couple of splits to avoid spitting out of the circle early. The trail is well-marked though, so just take note of the map and pay attention to the signs. Signs that point towards parking lot will spit you out early. Graveyard Hill is the toughest climb, but there are a couple of bypasses that allow you to miss it if you want. Interesting fact, there's an old graveyard back there, it's not just named Graveyard Hill because it puts you in the graveyard. {"url": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/7003800/south-branch-loop", "title": "South Branch Loop", "difficulty": "Intermediate", "trailhead": "https://maps.google.com/?daddr=38.683342,-77.209202", "gpx": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/gpx/7003800", "info-text": {"description": "South Branch Loop is the backbone of the trail system at Meadowood Special Recreation Management area. Built by volunteers from local IMBA Chapter MORE and BLM staff working together, South Branch was the first singletrack trail constructed at Meadowood. It is accessible via three trailheads, the primary one at the Mason Neck Gateway kiosk on Gunston Road, and two satellite lots on Old Colchester Road and Belmont Boulevard.\r\n\nSouth Branch's rolling singletrack winds through mature hardwood forests along the sides of the South Branch of Massey Creek's stream valley. Expect tight turns, mellow berms, grade reversals, and wooden boardwalks over floodplains and wetlands. South Branch is a great hike on it's own, and is the perfect place for all levels of hiker to increase their off-road skills before tackling some of the area's more technical trails.\r\n\nHiking clockwise, hikers face a sustained climb out of the South Branch stream valley, and short, rolling downhills. Counterclockwise, the long (for Fairfax!) descent to the stream valley is your reward for tackling the numerous short climbs back to the ridge.\r\n\nSouth Branch holds up well to moderate precipitation but is prone to the freeze-thaw cycle in the winter months. Please be mindful of trail closures posted on the BLM or MORE's  (the local mountain bike club that maintains the trail) website, at the trailheads, or at the kiosks along the South Branch Loop.", "features": "Birding \u00b7 Fall Colors \u00b7 River/Creek \u00b7 Wildlife", "condition": "All Clear"}, "photo": "https://www.hikingproject.com/photo/7053990/boardwalk-spanning-the-flood-plain-of-massey-creek-on-the-south-branch-loop", "ratings": {"rating": 4.3, "num_reviewers": 8}, "stats": {"dist": 3.6, "dist-type": "Loop", "alt-range": [146, 11], "alt-change": [281, 290], "avg-grade": 3.0, "max-grade": 9.0}},

{"url": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/7063676/pimmit-run-trail", "title": "Pimmit Run Trail", "difficulty": "Intermediate", "trailhead": "https://maps.google.com/?daddr=38.904757,-77.195655", "gpx": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/gpx/7063676", "info-text": {"description": "Originally constructed by Fairfax Trails and Streams, a multi-use trail volunteer group that pioneered the Cross County Trail, this trail is now maintained jointly by Fairfax Trails and Streams, the Potomac Heritage Trail Association and MORE. At each road crossing, when hiking from west to east, look for a small map and signpost detailing the next segment of the trail. The FCPA makes it easy to follow the twisty trail.\r\n\nThe Pimmit Run Trail begins at Great Falls St., just north of Kirby Road. This first short section is a fun warm-up for what is to come, with some turns and narrow sections right above the stream. Crossing Westmoreland St., you start the main event. The trail here is flat and will inspire thoughts of the Creek Trail at Wakefield Park. Be conscious of other trail users, as the trail is popular with mountain bikers, dog walkers and other local residents. This section ends with a run up to Old Dominion Road, be careful as you climb past the small staircase.\r\n\nAfter crossing Old Dominion, turn right on the bike path and left at the trail sign. This will bring you to the first crossing of Pimmit Run. A bit further through bamboo forests will bring you to the final road crossing at Chesterbrook Rd.\r\n\nCross the road and turn right, then left to the next stream crossing and a wide field section. The final stream crossing is at the end of the field. Cross the stream and turn left. All of a sudden, the houses that have lined the trails are pushed back, and the stream buffer zone widens. You'll find yourself wondering if you are 10 minutes from the Capitol, or out in the National Forest. The trail becomes rockier and more technical, with a short, ledgy bench cut section. Crossing the floodplain, there are numerous roots and logs to keep you on your toes. Take your final right at the star-shaped blaze and exit the trail onto Bryan Branch Road.\r\n\nThis trail entry represents the western portion of the trail. The eastern portion picks up at the Marie Butler-Leven Preserve off of Kirby Road. The first portion of the eastern segment is on Fairfax County Park Authority land (frequently overgrown), while the majority of the eastern segment is on National Park Service lands administered by the George Washington Parkway.", "condition": "Unknown"}, "ratings": {"rating": 3.2, "num_reviewers": 5}, "stats": {"dist": 4.3, "dist-type": "Point to Point", "alt-range": [360, 185], "alt-change": [19, 186], "avg-grade": 1.0, "max-grade": 6.0}},

{"url": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/7063681/main-trail", "title": "Main Trail", "difficulty": "Intermediate", "trailhead": "https://maps.google.com/?daddr=38.862346,-77.117555", "gpx": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/gpx/7063681", "info-text": {"description": "Glencarlyn Park consists of the wooded hills and floodplain of Four Mile Run in south Arlington. It's a great park with ample parking, picnic pavilions, a nature center, and other attractions.\r\n\nThe trails at Glencarlyn are mostly sidehill singletrack through rocky soil and mountain laurel above the creek, with two loose loops on either side of the main parking area, connected by a paved multi-use path running the length of the park east to west. They hold up to wet weather great, and damp days often provide the best conditions, keeping the dust and gravel down and making sure the park is less packed with other visitors. \r\n\nThe route shown on the map is only a suggestion, as multiple trails parallel and intersect each other, and markings are few and far between. A great after-work hike contained entirely within the park is to link the two loose loops on either side of the main parking area into a figure-8 via the paved connector trail. Also not to be missed is the fun singletrack downhill from the hilltop parking lot west toward the Washington and Old Dominion rail trail (as shown on the map).\r\n\nWith ample parking and other amenities, Glencarlyn Park makes the ideal jumping-off point for out of town visitors, or folks driving in from other parts of the county.", "condition": "Unknown"}, "ratings": {"rating": 4.0, "num_reviewers": 1}, "stats": {"dist": 0.6, "dist-type": "Point to Point", "alt-range": [198, 146], "alt-change": [68, 34], "avg-grade": 3.0, "max-grade": 9.0}},

{"url": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/7064002/crane-trail-454", "title": "Crane Trail #454", "difficulty": "Difficult", "trailhead": "https://maps.google.com/?daddr=37.927599,-79.710039", "gpx": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/gpx/7064002", "info-text": {"description": "A very remote trail that seldom sees hikers, located almost entirely within the aptly named Rough Mountain Wilderness.  No summer views, but a good hike for a workout and for solitude.\r\n\nPrivate property borders Virginia Rt 42 on the western end of this trail, so there is no access there.  Eastern access is very difficult, requiring a long drive over dirt forest service roads that includes a stream ford.  The eastern end of the trail itself is also difficult to find. The best way to find it is to hike north from the access road along the railroad tracks (active route, with both freight and Amtrak traffic) until the tracks bridge a small stream. There should be a wooden kiosk at this point, but downed trees still make the trail difficult to find. It is best found using a GPS receiver.\r\n\nOnce it starts climbing Rough Mountain, the trail is easy to follow and in pretty good shape. It crests the ridge (you can bushwhack from here south to Griffith Knob for great views) and then heads west down to private property. Likely due to care from adjoining landowners, the western part of the trail is in much better shape than the eastern section. Just be sure to turn around at the National Forest boundary.", "condition": "Unknown"}, "photo": "https://www.hikingproject.com/photo/7067184/view-northeast-from-crane-trail-near-summit-of-rough-mountain", "stats": {"dist": 3.0, "dist-type": "Point to Point", "alt-range": [2543, 1368], "alt-change": [1161, 1177], "avg-grade": 15.0, "max-grade": 44.0}},

Please allow 2.5 hours for this as a hike. The trail takes you over the land in which one of the most decisive attacks of the entire Civil War took place. \r\n\nOn April 2, 1865, some 14,000 Unions soldiers crossed eight hundred yards of open ground and attacked 2,800 Confederates manning a line of earthworks protecting access to Petersburg. {"url": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/7068521/frog-run-trail", "title": "Frog Run Trail", "difficulty": "Intermediate", "trailhead": "https://maps.google.com/?daddr=38.880978,-77.437886", "gpx": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/gpx/7068521", "info-text": {"description": "A paved path with lots of spur trails leading out into the neighborhood. It connects into the Frog Run Trail that heads east toward Stringfellow Road. Across Walney Road and over the bridge from the trailhead, the Flatlick Trail continues west toward the Cub Run Trail system.\r\n\nA small ford across Frog Lick is usually navigable but may not be after strong storms or snow melt; though the entire route is generally easy, the ford's stepping stones may be too far apart for small children. I'm 5 feet tall and they're just a bit of a stretch for me. \r\n\nThe park authority is pretty good about clearing fallen logs etc. from the path, but the pavement quality is so-so due to root buckling and general erosion.\r\n\nFrom the northeast end of this map, a singletrack trail continues north toward Willard Road and Rt. 50; however, as of this time (January 2019), that section is closed for maintenance. \r\n\nAs a hike, it's nothing to go out of your way for. But if you work in the area, it's the perfect length for a lunchtime workout.", "features": "River/Creek", "condition": "Unknown"}, "ratings": {"rating": 3.0, "num_reviewers": 1}, "stats": {"dist": 0.9, "dist-type": "Point to Point", "alt-range": [303, 255], "alt-change": [50, 6], "avg-grade": 1.0, "max-grade": 5.0}},
{"url": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/7074296/devils-fork-loop-trail-401", "title": "Devil's Fork Loop Trail #401", "difficulty": "Intermediate/Difficult", "trailhead": "https://maps.google.com/?daddr=36.819362,-82.629079", "gpx": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/gpx/7074296", "info-text": {"description": "Did this in December, took the clockwise route as suggested. There were 10-12 stream crossings that were very challenging. A few of them can be navigated just staying on dry portions of rock, but most had rocks that were just too far apart to take a step. Solutions include bushwacking off the trail to find a better spot to cross, carefully making your way across fallen logs, or just take off your shoes and trudging through the ice cold water. \r\n\nAside from the initial stream crossings, the trail is not very challenging beyond Devil's Bathtub. There is a sign saying something like \"Warning: next 5 miles very strenuous and rugged\", but it was a relatively easy hike through the woods compared to the first part of the trail. First 2-3 miles took 3 hours to hike, remaining 5 miles took 2.5 hours hike. \r\n\nOverall it was a lot of fun; navigating the stream crossings added an element of challenge and decision-making.", "features": "River/Creek \u00b7 Swimming", "condition": "All Clear"}, "photo": "https://www.hikingproject.com/photo/7057085/pilgrim-navigating-one-of-many-stream-crossings", "ratings": {"rating": 4.8, "num_reviewers": 5}, "stats": {"dist": 6.8, "dist-type": "Loop", "alt-range": [2937, 1706], "alt-change": [1322, 1309], "avg-grade": 7.0, "max-grade": 25.0}},
{"url": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/7099512/dark-hollow-trail", "title": "Dark Hollow Trail", "difficulty": "Intermediate/Difficult", "trailhead": "https://maps.google.com/?daddr=36.902089,-82.774346", "gpx": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/gpx/7099512", "info-text": {"description": "This 1.3 mile out and back trail begins at a gated access road at the end of Cold Springs Road in Appplachia. NOTE: There is no parking at the trailhead. \r\n\nThe trail follows the graveled road and is relatively easy hiking for the first 0.5 miles. At approximately 0.65 miles you come to a powerline clear cut. The road forks here. Take the right hand, yellow-blazed fork uphill. You'll head uphill and reach a gap at 0.75 miles. Look for double blazes indicating a turn back and steeply uphill to the right.  \r\n\nYou'll then reach the powerline clearing again. The trail turns left and follows the power line clear cut. The trail will then descend into a gap and then right back uphill to the ridgetop. Just after a mile you'll find a sign indicating the trail continues straight ahead and downhill. This is an \"unofficial\" extension of the trail downhill to the Powell River Trail.  \r\n\nThis description does NOT cover that portion of the trail. Turn to the right and climb the steep trail to the ridge top. The trail, still yellow-blazed, enters the woods on the north side of the ridge here. The trail turns downhill for a short stretch but will turn back up hill over the quarter mile and you'll reach the powerline clearing and the overlook.  The trail is then back the same route.", "features": "Fall Colors \u00b7 Views", "condition": "Unknown"}, "photo": "https://www.hikingproject.com/photo/7076660/this-is-the-view-from-the-overlook-awaiting-your-effort", "ratings": {"rating": 4.0, "num_reviewers": 1}, "stats": {"dist": 1.4, "dist-type": "Point to Point", "alt-range": [2310, 1844], "alt-change": [544, 147], "avg-grade": 9.0, "max-grade": 24.0}},

The path crosses Churchill Road at one point, at a marked crosswalk, in a relatively quiet residential neighborhood. \r\n\nThe park (currently undergoing improvement to include stream restoration and tree planting) is a quiet and flat stretch that runs along Dead Run Stream and offers pleasant views of trees, birds, and some lovely homes. \r\n\nThis path is not well lit so bring a flashlight if you're out after dark. We found this to be a nice little walk with our young daughter, particularly when we need to burn off some steam - and best of all, it ends (or begins) at the library and community center, both of which have restrooms available during daytime hours.", "features": "River/Creek", "condition": "Minor Issues"}, "ratings": {"rating": 4.0, "num_reviewers": 1}, "stats": {"dist": 0.6, "dist-type": "Point to Point", "alt-range": [262, 230], "alt-change": [32, 6], "avg-grade": 1.0, "max-grade": 4.0}},

{"url": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/7086891/loop-1", "title": "Loop 1", "difficulty": "Intermediate", "trailhead": "https://maps.google.com/?daddr=36.775296,-76.161011", "gpx": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/gpx/7086891", "info-text": {"description": "This short 0.6 mile loop is relatively flat with some roots along the path. The loop is frequently visited by people in the birding community for its abundance in bird species including woodpeckers, Bald Eagles, owls and migratory waterfowl. \r\n\n\nThe trail begins by hiking over a small wooden foot-bridge. The loop begins and ends here so you can go left or right. By taking a right you begin by hiking along the swamps of Stumpy Lake. There is an abundance of cypress trees. Waterfowl, egrets and herons are seen along this section of the trail. About 0.2 miles into the trail you'll encounter a footbridge built by boy scouts. After the footbridge the low lying areas of the swamp to your right begin to disappear as you enter into more hardwood forest. \r\n\nHalfway through the loop turn left to stay on Loop 1 (Loop 2 continues straight). Stay on Loop 1 until you reach another intersection. Take a right for Loop 2. Take a left to stay on Loop 1. You'll go through a few large groves of Paw-Paw trees. The trail continues back to the trailhead. This trail is wide and mulched in some areas. {"url": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/7108885/green-trail-shared-use", "title": "Green Trail Shared Use", "difficulty": "Easy/Intermediate", "trailhead": "https://maps.google.com/?daddr=38.689877,-77.771053", "gpx": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/gpx/7108885", "info-text": {"description": "Parking at the trailhead is at the Fauquier Education Farm. Navigate to 8428 Meetze Road. Signs point the way to the trail access at the far end of the parking lot. A fence divides the parking area from the Warrenton Greenway, which ends at the point where traffic turns into the parking lot from Meetze Road. \r\n\nThe trail begins along the fence line to the left of the sign board, staying to the left of the barn where the first trail post can be found. The trail is fairly easy, crossing gently rolling farmland right-of-way. The trail sometimes parallels horse trails and at other times shares the horse trails. There are several turns for  various horse trails where it's not too clear which way is the hiking trail -- but the hiking trail is marked by posts with a hiker symbol.  \r\n\nThe trail ends at the Laurel Ridge connector trail, which continues to the parking lot of Laurel Ridge Community College. An out and back hike to the college parking lot from the trailhead off Meetze Road is about 2.9 miles. One could also park at the college and hike in the opposite direction, or park along the Warrenton Greenway and extend a walk on the Greenway to the Stafford Farm Trail.", "condition": "Unknown"}, "ratings": {"rating": 3.0, "num_reviewers": 1}, "stats": {"dist": 1.0, "dist-type": "Point to Point", "alt-range": [538, 444], "alt-change": [133, 67], "avg-grade": 4.0, "max-grade": 20.0}},
